- I made no such charge as is alleged by the honorable member for Parramatta.
- I heard it.

- The whole difficulty is that the reply I am endeavouring to make to the extravagant utterances of the honorabe member for Wakefield is of a character to rile the honorable member for Parramatta, and with the acuteness characteristic of him, the honorable member seeks to create an impression in another direction in order to lessen the severity of the castigation which he knows the honorable member for Wakefield is deserving of. I come now to another feature of the remarks made by the honorable member for Wakefield, to the effect that supervision, in so far as public works are concerned in the Home 'Affairs Department, and under the Government generally, is of such a character that men are not giving an adequate return for the wages paid to them. The honorable member must know that he is making charges against inspectors, foremen, supervising engineers, and, in fact, against men in official positions throughout the Public Service. So far as I understand the situation, every officer in the Government service knows well the policy of the Ministry, and that they are expected to get a fair return from all under them in the execution of their duty. If, as alleged by the honorable member for Wakefield, there are public officers who are not properly supervising the work intrusted to them; if there are officers whose supervision is insufficient to prevent those under them neglecting their work, it is the bounden duty of the honorable member to tell us who those officers are. It is not the duty of any honorable member to rise in his place in this House and make a general charge to the effect that the supervision of Government works is of such a character that loafers and wasters are continued in the employment df the Government. If there are loafers and wasters employed, responsible officers have neglected their duty. The honorable member for Wakefield has never specified any officer here or anywhere else. We have nothing but reckless charges, and it is most unfortunate that, in such circumstances, any honorable member, under cover of the privileges of Parliament, should attempt to malign public officers or those under them. If ' there are any manual workers in Government employ who, as alleged- by the honorable member, are loafers or wasters, it is his duty, and the duty of every other honorable member who knows of such a thing, to bring the matter before Parliament. If there be one such case, or the matter be somewhat trivial, it is at least the duty of any honorable member who knows it to bring it before the Minister concerned. I venture to suggest that no Minister at present occupying the Treasury bench, and no honorable gentleman who previously occupied it, would neglect to have such a matter investigated at once, and, if the charge were proved, to have the offender summarily dismissed from the Public Service. I can appeal, despite the little differences we have occasionally, to honorable members opposite to say whether it is a fair thing for any member of this House to come here in a fine, large, general way, with acknowledged inability, and without data, to specify a single instance of what is complained of, and assert that the inspectorial staff are not doing their duty, and are conniving, and winking the eye, at the employment of loafers and wasters. It is distinctly unfair in the circumstances. If I knew of an instance of such a thing, it would be my duty to call attention to it. If it were an isolated case, or there were one or two instances of the kind, I should feel it my duty to go to the Minister concerned. The honorable member for Wakefield, who tells us that he knows of these things from his own personal observation, has deliberately neglected his duty. If he is personally aware of instances of the employment of loafers and wasters in the Public Service, he should have called the attention of the Minister concerned to the fact. He should have specified the particular instances, that the Minister might be in a position to make inquiries on the spot. But, as a matter of fact, now that the honorable member has cooled down, he knows that he has been making wild, reckless, and extravagant charges.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - No, he does not. He will make them again.

- The honorable member says that he does not, and that he will make these charges again.; but he knows that he has been making reckless charges. There is no evidence to substantiate his statement, which, so far as I can see, was made only on the strength of a statement published in the press to the effect that something is wrong in the Government Service. There has been some confusion as to which Department is concerned. Some newspapers have asserted that it is in the Home Affairs Department, and others that it is in the Post and Telegraph Department. The honorable member for Wakefield, with his usual carelessness, has seized hold of these allegations and proceeded to make still more reckless charges, on the strength of allegations that appeared, where ? In the newspapers. Let me put the position plainly to the honorable member. Suppose there were certain persons in Australia who were about to have some dealings with the honorable member, and desired some proof of his bona -fides. Would he send them to the Daily Herald, of South Australia, for a character, or. to the Sydney Worker, or the Brisbane Worker t

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - I should not need to send them to any one.

- Oh, yes, the honorable member would. Would he send them to the Labour Call, in Victoria ? He knows that he would send them where h"e thought they would get an opinion which would see him through his difficulty, if he had one.
- The. newspapers referred to would give the honorable member a bad character, I suppose?

- Those that know the honorable member. This is all political, of course. Because some statement appears in a newspaper, which every one knows does its best to injure this side of the House, the honorable member seizes the opportunity to make a charge which he must now very much regret. I respect very highly the utterances by the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy 'Leader of the Opposition, both of whom dealt with the matter in such a manner as to meet with the approval of every honorable member. They spoke, as they ought to do, as members of the Opposition, whose duty it is to criticise this side with a full appreciation of the responsibility attaching to their position. Neither honorable gentleman so far forgot himself as to make wild, extravagant, reckless charges without a shadow of foundation, and then seek, because of statements appearing in a newspaper called the Argus, to have appointed a Select Committee to in- quire into the allegations made. Supposing that by some awful catastrophe honorable members opposite were in power, and the Daily Herald, of Adelaide, or the Worker, of New South Wales or Queensland, or the Labour Call, of Victoria, made some statements respecting their administration, would they immediately ask the House to appoint a Select Committee?
- They ought to challenge inquiry.
- They ought, as we always do.
- Does not the Honorary Minister think that the Minister in charge of this work should make a statement to the House as to the methods of his procedure ?
- I am going to make a statement; I have not been given a " show " yet.

- I have no doubt that the Minister will make -a statement, and I have expressed the opinion that both the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader have only done their duty to the public and to the House. I should not have intruded in this debate but for the fact that honorable members opposite have not copied their leaders, but have gone off at a tangent, and made statements of which they must feel ashamed in their cool moments. Something has been said about some railway tender in South Australia, in regard to which misrepresentations may be made to the public. It was desired to construct a few miles of railway from Tailem Bend to Brown's Well, and, under the legislation of South Australia, it is always necessary to call for public tenders. The Public Works Department of that State sometimes tenders in competition with private contractors, and there have been times when these departmental tenders have justified the Government in accepting them.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - 1 can reply to that very nicely.

- There are other times, of course, when the departmental tenders have not been of such a character as to justify their acceptance. I believe that when the honorable member for Wakefield was a member of the South Australian Parliament, tenders by the officers of the Public Works Department were accepted. Recently, when a Labour Ministry was in office in the State Parliament, trie departmental tender for this particular few miles of railway was refused, and a private one accepted. That is all that there is in the charge made.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - That is an absolutely incorrect statement.
- What was the difference between the two tenders?
- Some thousands of pounds.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - The difference was 62 £ per cent.

- The Public Works tender, I believe, was £150,000, while the private tender was £80,000 or ,£90,000. Honorable members know that when contractors do not desire to undertake a particular piece of work they make their tender so high as to insure its being rejected, though they never neglect to put in a tender. So it is with the Public Works Department. When the Department wishes to undertake a work it tenders at a price that it is believed will be accepted; and, in such circumstances, they invariably obtain a contract, and the work is carried out to the advantage of all concerned. In other circumstances the Department adopts the method of _ outside contractors, and tenders at a price that they know will not be accepted.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - The Public Works Department's tender is the Departmental estimate of the cost of the work.

- I have shown all that there is in the statement made by the honorable member for Wakefield, who ought not to seek to make the public believe that the tender of the Public Works Department is abnormally high, because of the necessity of paying high wages, or because, as alleged by him, the Government can get only loafers and wasters to work for them, while private contractors have the services of men out of whom they can knock a greater amount of work. I hope that, although some little heat has been caused by the utterances of the honorable member for Wakefield, that gentleman, now that he has had time for reconsideration, will-
- Apologize to the House.
- Apologize, not to the House, but to the officers of the Department of Home Affairs, and the men employed therein.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - I rise to a point of order. The Honorary Minister, before resuming his seat, made a statement that was absolutely and wilfully incorrect.
- That is not a point of order.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - Then I say these few words as a personal explanation.
- I ask that the honorable member for Wakefield be compelled to withdraw his allegation that the Honorary Minister made a statement that was "absolutely and wilfully incorrect."
- If the Honorary Minister considers the words offensive I am sure the honorable member for Wakefield will withdraw them.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - I withdraw the words, but I ask you, Mr. Chairman, to insist on the Honorary Minister withdrawing his statement.

- I think the honorable member for Wakefield had better leave the Honorary Minister to me. I desire to make a personal explanation. This is the statement of the Honorary Minister which I took exception to at the time, and it is quite evident he was not aware of what he was saying -

quote.para: Perhaps the time has arrived when honorable members on the opposite side may be given to understand that, while it is their bounden duty to criticise, and while it is their duty to call the attention of the House and the public generally to anything that has been done of a character that ought not to be done, or to any errors of the Ministry, good, bad, or indifferent, yet it is not their duty, under cover of Parliamentary privilege to assert that all the persons working in the Home Affairs Department are loafers and wasters.

speech.para: There is an implied statement, applied to the whole of the Opposition, that we charge the persons working in the Department as loafers and wasters.

talk.start.para: - How does the honorable member get this in as a " personal explanation " ?

- T say that I was quite justified in requiring the withdrawal of those expressions, which contain an implied charge that we on this side make a wholesale accusation against the officers and persons working in the Home Affairs Department of being loafers and wasters. No such accusation was made, and it ought not to be attributed to the Opposition by the Honorary Minister.

. - I should not have risen but for the attitude on this side in relation to the utterances of the honorable member, for Wakefield. To some extent I am not with " my own people " on the question. I take it that if charges are made against the administration of a Commonwealth Department, it is the duty of the Ministers concerned to at once give attention to the charges. The

speech.para: Argus is a "big" newspaper, and no one can deny the fact; any statement made in that newspaper, reflecting on Departmental administration, should not be passed lightly over. I submit that the honorable member for Wakefield did the right thing, and I take exception to the attack to which he has been subjected by honorable members on this side of the chamber, and to the attempt which was made to howl him down. I desire an investigation into the charges which have been preferred against the day-labour system by the Argus newspaper. If those charges be correct, let the existing condition of things be remedied1 at the earliest possible moment, but if the allegations be untrue, let us pin that journal down to a deliberate mis-statement of fact. Because a member of the Opposition deems it his duty to take a certain course of action in the public interest, surely it is not for honorable members upon this side of the chamber to attack- him, to repudiate his utterance, and to attempt to howl him down. I say that it is a wrong thing to do. Even the Minister of Home Affairs himself to-day replied to a question in a manner which did not redound to his credit. When a newspaper like the Argus prefers definite charges against a Department, it is idle to tell me that it is afflicted with Chinese leprosy. Such an answer does not afford a solution of the problem which we have to face. The Government must see - especially when we are attempting to carry out contracts under the day-labour system - that that system is effective, that the inspectors engaged upon them do their duty, or that they go out, and that men who will not do their work go out with them. It is the duty of the Government and of every Minister to answer the charges made by the Argus, and to prove that they are false. If they cannot do that, they stand condemned.

talk.start.para: - No.
- I say " Yes." It is enough for me to know that there was a column of matter in the Argus setting out that men engaged on our public works are in the habit of loafing.
- It is easy enough to make that statement.

- And it is easy enough lo repudiate it. From the Labour stand-point, when a great newspaper prefers charges against a public Department, it is the duty of the Government to demonstrate that they are false. If the allegations be not true they can be easily disproved.

talker.party: ALP
talker.name: MOLONEY, Parker
Mr PARKER MOLONEY

talk.start.para: - The Government would need to do nothing else if it adopted that course.

- That may be so. The Argus deliberately affirms that men are leaving their work, although they are paid to do it, that they are drunk at their work, that they refuse to do their duty, and that they simply flout their superior officers. If that be so, the position is a very serious one. Certainly a statement of that character ought to be at once inquired into by the Government. Let us investigate the matter, and justify our officers, who, I hope, are discharging their duties effectively, and at the same time let us redeem the men of the odium which will otherwise attach to them. I know that the daily press are accustomed to cast slurs upon the Labour party. They attack the Government because they desire to show that our methods are not in the best interests of this country. But when they make charges it is the duty of the Government to reply to them with such effectiveness as will sweep them off the face of the earth, at least for some time. I think, too, that some inefficiency has been exhibited in carrying out works in the Federal Territory. I am not satisfied when I find that there was an unexpended vote there last year of £31,000. I am not satisfied that there ought not to be more money on the Estimates for the Federal Territory for the current financial year. I have a very keen suspicion that the Minister of Home Affairs has been subjected to certain Victorian pressure. I am not unaware that at the recent by-election, while sitting in my room, I heard a member of my own party, who entertains a Victorian prejudice - he calls himself a Nationalist - say-
- It is the worst of parliamentary etiquette to refer to anything that one hears in one's room.

- I admit that, and I am sorry I was about to offend. But I am perfectly sure that certain influences have operated with the Minister of Home Affairs. I sincerely trust that the Government will strive to push to completion the buildings in the Federal Capital. The site has been selected, the design of the city has been approved, and the only thingcnow remaining is to put the work in hand as soon as possible, and carry it to completion.

. - Ever since I have been a member of this Parliament I have been impressed by the fact that time after time Ministers will ask Parliament to authorize a particular vote, will dwell upon its extreme urgency, emphasize the necessity which exists for it being at once proceeded with, and yet, at the end of the year, that vote will be found to be unexpended. For works in Tasmania last year £17,419 was voted, of which only £4,000 was expended, and we are now asked to approve of the expenditure of £11,497of the original sum. In other words, not 20 per cent. of the vote was expended. Now, either these works are necessary or they are not. If they are not, they ought not to be submitted to Parliament; if they are, they should be proceeded with, and the money should be expended within the financial year. It is not enough to say that the State officers are in fault. I am sure the Minister of Home Affairs will agree with me when I say that he has one of the most efficient officers in Australia at the head of the Works Department in Tasmania, and I am satisfied that any delay which has occurred in pushing forward works there does not lie at his door. If there be one thing which stands out more prominently than another in connexion with our public works system, it is the absolute necessity which exists for appointing a permanent Public Works Committee to overlook and report on all important public undertakings.
- It ought to have been appointed long ago.

- From inquiries which I have made, I believe that honorable members on both sides of the Chamber, as well as the members of the State Parliament, are unanimous in their testimony that the New South Wales Public Works Committee has proved of inestimable value, in that it has prevented the useless expenditure of hundreds of thousands of pounds. If a necessity exists for the appointment of such a body in a State, how much more pressing is that necessity in connexion with the public works of the Commonwealth ? For instance, honorable members may be asked to approve of a vote for a work in Western Australia or in Queensland. How can the representatives of, say, Tasmania be expected to know what warrant there is for assenting to a public work in Queensland ? We have either to vote for it blindly, or to oppose it blindly. It is not fair to honorable members or to their constituents to ask them to vote enormous sums, such as we shall be asked to vote for many years to come, without having the slightest knowledge of the necessity for the proposed expenditure, or of the manner in which the money is to be expended. As regards the mode in which works are carried out under the day-labour system, I, for one, will not accept the position which the Honorary Minister has asked us to take. It is not the duty of a member of Parliament to go spying about tunnels and underground works to see whether men are working fairly or not, and then make a report to the Minister. I refuse to become an informer, even to oblige the Minister, whose duty and privilege it is to see that the work is properly carried out. Persons have come to me, and made certain statements, but I have refused to voice them publicly, and will not do so. These statements should be made before a proper Inquiry Board. The present position cannot be allowed to continue. In connexion with the construction of overland railways and the Federal Capital, and in other directions, we shall be called upon, during the next few years, to spend from £15,000,000 to £25,000,000. The policy of the Government is that public works shall be carried out by day labour. It is the bounden duty of the Government and the House to see that the money is fairly and properly expended. I cannot understand the attitude of a Minister who allows these charges to be made inside the House, and out of it, without challenging an inquiry.
- Has there been one specific charge made?
- There have been plenty of charges made in the Argus.
- Has there been one charge made in this House?

- I think that there have been sufficient charges made to warrant the Minister in demanding that an inquiry should be held. This is one of those business propositions of which the Minister of Home Affairs is so very much in favour. These charges are made, not only publicly, but privately, wherever one goes. Were I in the Minister's place, I should challenge an inquiry, and would not wait for a private member to move for the appointment of a Select Committee. The very honour of his Department is involved. I am not making one charge against either the Minister or any member of his staff ; but I hold that when such charges are made it is the duty of the Government, as well as of the Minister, to seek the fullest possible inquiry. If the honorable gentleman has nothing to fear - and I do not express an opinion on that point -he should not wait for the notice of motion on the business-paper to be dealt with.
- I expect that he has already asked his officers to report on the charges.
- If the Minister has taken that step, and a report has been made to him, it should be laid upon the table of the House at once.

talker.party: ALP
talker.name: MOLONEY, Parker
Mr PARKER MOLONEY

talk.start.para: - The honorable member does want things done suddenly. This is the first day we have ever heard of the charges.
- This is not the first that we have heard of the charges.
- Which charges?

- That the work of the Department is not carried out in a satisfactory way. I cannot think that any honorable member on the other side can have any purpose to serve in trying to prevent an inquiry from being held. It is in the interests of the policy in which honorable members opposite believe - the day-labour system - and also in the interests of the taxpayers, who will be called upon to find from £15,000,000 to £20,000,000 during the next few years to carry out public works, that we should have an assurance that the money which is voted for public works will be expended to the best advantage. Whilst the officers of the Department give a fair day's pay for a fair day's work, they should see that a fair day's work is given for a fair day's pay.

.- The honorable member for Dalley has anticipated, to some extent, what I intended to say in regard to the alleged inefficiency of the oversight of the construction of public works. A few days ago I asked the Minister of Home Affairs - and I was in error in doing so, I understand - if he had noticed the article regarding this matter which has been referred to several times here to-day. I should have addressed the question to the Postmaster-General. It does not lessen the gravity of the charge whether it was laid against the Minister of Home Affairs, or against his colleague. It was a very serious charge, indeed, and one which, if based on a semblance of fact at all, discloses a scandalous state of affairs. If the charge is not true, it should be investigated at once, and nailed down to the counter as a lie. The Minister, not for his own credit, not for the credit of the Cabinet, but also for the credit of his officers, should have the matter investigated. They are not in a position themselves to conduct an investigation.
- The responsible Minister is investigating the matter.

- It is some days since I asked the Minister of Home Affairs if he had noticed the article in the Argus, and if he intended to get a report. There is nothing very mysterious about a report in this connexion. There are officers in the Department, and any report submitted by them might be substantiated or otherwise by architects and engineers in outside practice who are competent to express an opinion on this matter. There is no rule-of-thumb in this business ; matters of this kind are now reduced to an exact science. The officers in the Department can say exactly what a lineal or cubic yard of excavation should cost in a certain description of ground ; so they should be able to tell, to 1s., what a rod of brickwork ought to cost. They ought to know the cost of material. If they do not possess this knowledge, they should not be in their present position. I believe, from my knowledge of the officers, that they know all these things. Not only should the Minister get a report from the officers of his Department, but he should also have their report corroborated by outside persons. Parliament has a right to know whether these charges, which are made by a newspaper - which, I frankly admit, loses no opportunity to flog honorable members on this side and the present Ministry - are true or false. When such a charge is made, it is the duty of the Postmaster-General, or whoever may be acting for him during his illness, which we all regret, or the Minister of Home Affairs, to see that it is thoroughly investigated at once.
- It is being investigated by the Department.

- The investigation should be prompt, thorough, and reliable. The Prime Minister took no notice of a matter of which I should have taken serious notice; I refer to certain charges made against the Treasurer. He should not sit down quietly under such accusations.
- I corrected the misstatements that were published.
- And the press failed to give the corrections. It is that to which I take exception.
- Is the honorable member of opinion that Parliament should appoint a Committee to inquire into every press allegation?

- No; but this is so serious a matter that it should be investigated. Let honorable members read the statement of the Secretary for Public Works in New South Wales, which appears in to-day's newspapers. The honorable member for Wakefield referred to a railway contract, but spoke on hearsay. Let me give a personal experience. I am not hostile to the Government, nor am I hostile to the day-labour system. As a matter of fact, I am in favour of the day-labour system, because I know the results that can be obtained from it. . The last work on which I was engaged before I entered this Parliament was a railway contract, in connexion with which I acted as an inspector. Tenders were called for 44 miles of railway in Queensland, and the lowest offer was £98,000. The line was to be carried out under the joint control of three local authorities, which were borrowing from the Government, and they came to the conclusion that it would be cheaper to employ day labour than to accept the lowest tender. The necessary hands were engaged, and supervisors were appointed. It is the supervision that is generally the weak thing about Government works. Where the supervisors are not men of character, work will always cost more than it should cost. In the case to which I refer, the line was constructed by day labour for £17,000 less than the lowest tender, the minimum wage paid being 8s. a day, though nearly every man on the job was getting 10s. a day or over, and, although the specifications required 720 cubic yards of ballast to the mile, we provided 1,000 cubic yards, put in additional bridges, made all the sidings, and built all the stations needed. Whenever men came along, as sometimes happened, with a note from the Chairman of the Joint Board, saying, " Please find this man a job," or words to that effect, they were told to go to a much warmer climate than Victoria is enjoying at the present time. The position taken up by the man in charge was, " I am responsible for this work. I have to see that it is done reasonably, cheaply, though without sweating, and I am determined, therefore, to choose my own men, and not to accept all who are sent to me."
- The days have gone when men could take up that position.
- No, they have not.
- In those days, unsuitable workers were dismissed. '

- That happens now under supervisors who have sufficient force of character. Such a man should be able to say to a worker, "I do not care a tinker's curse whether you appeal to a Minister or to a member of Parliament. You are not good enough for this work, and I will not have you on it. I can always get a job elsewhere if my own independence is found fault with."
- What would happen if the man dismissed was a unionist?

- The less the honorable member says about unionism the better, because he belongs to a body of men who, while professing not to be unionists, have- what is known as an honorable understanding, which makes them practically unionists. The Minister of Home Affairs is now being asked to undertake too much. One Minister cannot properly control meteorology, statistics, electoral administration, and works and railway constructions. The present Minister will not occasionally take a little drop of refreshment upstairs, and owing to the strenuous life which he is leading one can see that he is going to pieces. If l call in at his office at 9 o'clock in the morning. I find that he has already been there for half-an-hour or more, yet all he takes to sustain him is a little drop of hot milk. His responsibility is too great for any one man, and should be divided. I do not know that I favour the appointment of a Works Committee composed of members of Parliament. In this House we have very few practical men. I do not see one on the other side, though, of course, the honorable member for Fremantle, who is away, is a practical man. On this side we have the honorable members for Maranoa, East Sydney, Gwydir, and South Sydney, and I, myself, am a practical man.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - Why these invidious distinctions?

- I apologize' for omitting the honorable member. I know him to be a practical man. With the exceptions I have named, there are no men in this Chamber competent, in my opinion, to form a Works Committee, lt is questionable, too, whether a Parliamentary Committee could do what would be required of a Works Committee. Such a body would have to occasionally visit works in progress, arid this often could not be done with parliamentary duties to be attended to. I understand that the New South Wales Public Works Committee deals only with railway proposals, recommending or reporting against, them as it sees fit. General works it knows nothing about, and it is not asked to know anything about them.
- It inquires concerning all works the estimated cost of which exceeds £20,000.

- It recommends the works, but does not supervise them. We want something more than a recommendation, because this Parliament does the recommending. I now come into conflict with the honorable member for Dalley in regard to the money being spent on the Federal Capital site. It is an absolute waste of money, and an injustice to Australia. The less money put upon the Estimates for the purpose, the better, and here, too, complaints are being made in regard to works being carried out by day labour. With regard to day labour, at a certain port in my electorate money is being borrowed from the State Government to build a breakwater and a viaduct. There . is almost an open roadstead there, the harbor being to a small extent sheltered by an island. The intention is to build from the island a breakwater extending north, and from the southern end of the island a viaduct in the neighbourhood of. 3 miles long to connect with the mainland. Mr. Cullen, the Chief Engineer for Harbors and Rivers in Queensland, made an official report on the matter some time ago, when the local authority asked the State Government for the loan of the money. In this report he said, amongst other things, that, whilst the breakwater might be built by contract, the viaduct, being a much more important work, and it being necessary for it to be perfectly stable and reliable, should be built by day labour. No higher testimony to day labour could be given than that statement, coming from a gentleman of Mr. Cullen's position and ex'perience. Every railway that has. been built in Queensland for a considerable time has been built by day labour, and there is no intention, so far as I know, to depart from the system.
- It is the same in Victoria.,

- I believe the same system is being followed in New South Wales also ; but I am speaking of the State with which I am most, intimately acquainted. In New South Wales, Mr. Griffith has stated that he is going to make a comparison between day labour and contract work by letting a contract for a certain length of railway, and building an equal length by day labour. I am afraid it is impossible to make a comparison in that way, because no two railways are identical. The country is not alike, sleepers are more difficult to get in one place than another; in one place there is more rock that earthwork ; and on one line there are more bridges to build than on another. If the Minister of Home Affairs tried to make a similar comparison here between contract work and day labour, he would be in the same position as the Minister for Works in New South Wales. The attempt would be an utter failure, and would give us no real testimony as to the relative merits of the two systems. I should like to remind the honorable member for Swan, who spoke about the amount of money that had to be revoted, that last year the Works Estimates came on very late. Parliament did not meet till late in the year, and naturally the Works Estimates were considered still later. Consequently, a lot of work was not finished; but there is no necessity whatever for the Department to wait until the Works Estimates are passed to have the plans and specifications prepared. No case is yet on record of any of these Estimates having been " turned down " after being submitted to Parliament; and there is no reason why the Department should not anticipate parliamentary approval of them, and be ready to proceed with the works as soon as the money is voted.
- Or even earlier.

- It might be done even earlier ; but the Department could anticipate the vote by Parliament. I am entirely opposed to the present system whereby the Minister of Home Affairs has to depend on the State Public Works Departments to have his works supervised and plans and specifications prepared. The time has now arrived for us to have a Works Department of our own. The honorable member for Lang and the honorable member for Franklin will confirm my statement as to what was going on at Thursday Island only recently. When the Pearl-shell Commission was there, a quarantine station was being built, and a jetty was also being built. The officer in charge of the work at the quarantine station was an officer of the Public Works Department of Queensland.

speech.para: That man does not care a button for the Minister of Home Affairs. He is in the employ of the State, and when the State is not working in harmony with the Commonwealth, as is the case with Queensland and some of the other States, the State authorities would rather back up their own officer, if he were in conflict with the Minister of Home Affairs, than do the reverse. If the Minister of Home Affairs said to this man, " Your work is not proceeding satisfactorily," he would go to his own Department, which would support him on every occasion. I am not making any reflection on the officer at Thursday Island. He is an efficient officer; but the system is very unsatisfactory, and should be superseded at the earliest moment by the establishment of a Federal Public Works Department, in which our own plans and specifications will be prepared by our own staff, and our own supervision engaged. The officers in it would be responsible to this Parliament, and no State Parliament should have control over them. I hope the Minister of Home Affairs will take into consideration the matter of which I have spoken. I have referred to it here before, but am sorry to say that my words of wisdom have fallen unheeded by him. He takes not the slightest notice of them. He goes on his own way, sometimes rejoicing, and sometimes the reverse. The Argus is flogging him just now, and he does not like it. If he would take advice that has been tendered to him from this side of the House, as well as from outside, he would possibly give less opportunity for these press criticisms.

talk.start.para: .- It is evident from these Public Works Estimates, which have been submitted to us to-day, that the Federal Government is rapidly becoming the largest employer of labour in Australia, if indeed it is not so already. Therefore, it is only prudent and wise that we should survey the manner in which many of our public works are being carried out, especially in reference to labour conditions. I do not intend to import any heat into this discussion.
- We wish to hear criticism.

- I know what it is to have been in office, and I know' that there are occasions on which the contract system is altogether inapplicable, and when the day-labour system must be adopted. I am not going to condemn clay labour. On the other hand, I am not going to advocate its universal adoption. Discrimination and great judgment have to be exercised by those responsible in deciding whether a particular work should be done by contract or by day labour. I know as a fact that many private enterprises are at the present time being carried out by day labour. Proprietors have" found it advisable, owing to the uncertainty of the labour market, to adopt that method. Indeed, they have been forced to do so, because of the high prices which contractors have to submit in tendering for a work in consequence of the uncertainty of the .labour market, and the liability to strikes. But certainly when day labour is resorted to the Federal Government as the employer ought to obtain guarantees and assurances, firstly, that every effort will be made to secure the services of the best nien who may be available ; secondly, that they shall be paid well ; and, thirdly, that they shall be expected and required- to do their duty.
- Quite Tight.
- If they will not do their duty they ought to be amenable to discipline.
- They ought to be " sacked."
- These are principles in which the Government ought to acquiesce.
- 1 say that such men ought to be dismissed. That is more than saying that they should be amenable to discipline.

- Discipline in the case of such conduct means dismissal in the end. I hope that if Ministers have any suspicion that those conditions are not being complied with in connexion with Government work some change will be made.
- Instructions have been given to that effect already.

- Otherwise great discredit will be brought upon Commonwealth Departments. Dealing in order with the three points which I have mentioned, I would draw attention to this fact: Whilst, with reference to the permanent hands employed by the Federal Government, . there are qualifications which conduce to the employment of the best men available, there is also a large area of employment within the control of the Federal Government as to which there' is no such guarantee. I refer to those work men who are regarded as outside the pale of the permanent Service, and who come within the category of casuals or exempt hands. Honorable members will be surprised if they make inquiries to find to what extent of late years the area of exempt or casual service has been extended.. Parliament, in framing the Public Service Act, made provision for the registration of applications for temporary employment in the office of the Commissioner. But I have found that of late years ' various Departments have gradually encroached uPon the system of registration, and have, indeed, been dispensing with* it altogether. They have relegated the engagement of casual employes either to inspectors or officials, or. have adopted some other indefinite and indeterminate mode. As a private member of this House, in common with other honorable members, I have been frequently asked by persons in search of employment how to obtain work in connexion with Commonwealth enterprises. I have advised these applicants to send ir* their names to the Public Service Commissioner, in order that they might be registered.
- Hear, hear !

- But I have found' that many men have had their names on the register for )'ears and have not been1 able to get a job. How is that ? The reason is that in the course of time the practice has grown up of not having resort to* the register in the engagement of casual' employes. I ask the Prime Minister to take a note of that fact.
- We want to know these things.

- The service-rendering and employment-giving Departments have been ignoring the requirements of the Public Service Act in reference to registration, and have resorted to the practice of engaging hands without reference to the Public Service Commissioner's employment register.
- I will inquire to-morrow.

- The law requires that men who want a casual job shall have their names registered, and shall be engaged in order of precedence. But I know more than one man in my own electorate, as well as others in different pasts of Victoria, whose names have been registered for years. Their hearts have been almost broken through failure to get a job after long waiting.
- Has the honorable member any idea as to what Departments have been following that practice?
- I believe that the practice is followed particularly by the Post and Telegraph Department.
- I will make inquiries tomorrow.
- I believe that the Public Service Commissioner is quite prepared to do his share of the work.
- If the honorable member will ask a question on the subject tomorrow, 1 will answer it.

- Of course, the Public Service Commissioner has nothing to do with the engaging of casual labour. His task is simply to keep a register. It is supposed that in practice men will be able to get a job by registering their names. That practice, if adhered to, would be to some extent a check. But I have ascertained that in actual practice the Post and Telegraph Department and the Home Affairs Department have been in the habit of engaging hands without reference to the Public Service Commissioner. The result is that unfortunate men whose names have been registered for years in the office of the Public Service Commissioner have been lamentably disappointed.
- .Hear, hear ! Quite right ! That is true.
- This is a matter that ought to be inquired into. There is a growing feeling that political patronage has been creeping into the Public Service during the last few years.
- The trouble is that men who register their names, afterwards get a job, and when we inquire for them, they are not to be found.

- So far as the temporary Service is concerned, the regulations require that certain tests and examinations shall be imposed by the departmental officers. It may be that even to that extent too much power is given to departmental officers, and that outsiders - men who are unknown to departmental officers - are unable to get a share of any work that is offering. The departmental officers may be actuated by bias or personal feeling and sympathy. These are questions that will have to be tackled, and if there is such a thing as political or departmental patronage, and if working men in the Commonwealth do not have a fair share of any Commonwealth employment that is going, we ought to know the reason why.
- Hear, hear !

- I do not disguise the fact that there is a suspicion of political, as well as departmental, patronage. The feeling has been growing that a man cannot obtain a billet under the Government unless he has a letter from a member of Parliament. It is thought by many that a letter from a member of Parliament, and particularly from a member of the Labour party, will prove an avenue to a Government billet.
- Is the honorable member referring to a position in the permanent service ?
- No, to the casual, or exempt, service.
- There should be no need for that kind of thing.

- Certainly not. I decline to give any one a letter of introduction or recommendation to any departmental officer. It should be beneath the dignity of a member of Parliament to do so. Such a thing ought not to be tolerated.

- I do not think the honorable member is quite correct in that view. If, for instance, we were anxious to obtain good miners, and the honorable member knew of one, he would be right in giving him a letter of recommendation.
- I would give him a certificate of character, but not directed to any individual.
- If an honorable member knew of a good man, he would be quite justified in recommending him to the Minister.
- I do not recommend a man to any particular Minister. I would give a man a certificate of good character, but that is the utmost limit to which I would go.
- -Why, the honorable member has recommended men.

- I have given letters of character, but no letters of recommendation to any political or departmental officer. The time has arrived when these matters ought to be inquired into, and the air cleared- I heard a charge made recently in this House against the administration of the employment conditions in connexion with the Federal Capital - a charge which has not yet been dealt with. If was made by the honorable member for Wilmot during the debate on the Address-in-Reply, and I wish now to bring it once more under the attention of the Prime Minister and the Minister of Home Affairs. Let us have some explanation or refutation of it, if either be possible. The charge made by the honorable member was based upon an article which appeared, not in the Argus, but in a technical periodical called Building, published in Sydney. It is the Sydney contractors' journal. Some time ago, that journal published an article in which complaint was made that workmen employed by the Department of Home Affairs in connexion with the Federal Capital were not giving a fair return for their wages, and that things were at sixes and sevens. The Department denied the accuracy of the charge, and then this journal, it appears, took steps to inquire into the accuracy of its first allegation. A man was sent to the Federal "Capital to watch what was going on, and to take notes, and, after remaining there for seven months, he made a report to Building, which returned to the attack in the article quoted by the honorable member for Wilmot. In that article, the following passage occurred -

quote.para: We can now unhesitatingly say, and are prepared to prove, that the day labour system of work at the Federal Capital site is a public scandal.
There is no system, but a " jumbled order of things, disgracing the administration of the Home Affairs Department, and retarding progress generally at the site."
The work is not only snail like, the men are not only at the lowest stage of demoralization as regards' honest labour, but the work itself is a disgrace to good construction.

That is the charge. I have no personal acquaintance with it, but I heard this statement read, and was somewhat staggered by it. I waited to hear a refutation, or an explanation, from the Department, but none has been given and, as we have been challenged to give some basis for our complaint, I have read this extract, and invite the Minister to make an explanation. I am not making any personal charge against the Minister. These things may be going on behind his back.

talk.start.para: - They are not going on.

- He should have some official, authentic report in explanation of these extraordinary charges. If a shirking of work is going on in connexion with the Federal Capital, it may be going on in such a manner that the public is not receiving value for its money. We are spending £100,000 a year in connexion with the Capital, and men are being employed by the Department on the day-labour system. I should like to know what precautions are taken to secure the best men for the work, and I should like some assurance that men are not appointed because of political opinion or political favoritism, lt is quite possible that, if men obtain employment because of political favoritism, they will not be so amenable to discipline as would others who got these appointments as the result of ordinary competitive examination or some test as to qualification.
- Does not the honorable member recognise that he has quoted from a biased source?
- I do not know the paper, but I think it would be well to follow up the allegations. I shall endeavour to do so.

speech.para: Mi. Ozanne. - The same sort of thing has been going on for centuries.

talk.start.para: - We are in Opposition at present, and we are dealing with the Government. Here is a specific case. If these things are being perpetrated at the present time, it is no answer to say that they were going on in times past. The Government is becoming such a great employer of labour in connexion with not only the Federal Capital, but the Northern Territory, and the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta railway, on which £5,000,000 will be spent, that the public are entitled to some assurance that public money will be well spent, and that there will be no shirking or loafing.
- They will get that assurance.

- If these men receive good wages and work eight hours a day, it is just as well that the public should have guarantees that they do their duty, and do honour and credit to those who employ them. So far as the Federal Capital is concerned, I am disposed to concur with the honorable member who has just resumed his seat, that under existing circumstances it is too great a burden for one man to carry, and that, notwithstanding the desire of the Minister to do what is right and proper, it is too much to expect him to be able to look after the multitudinous enterprises coming gradually within the jurisdiction of the Department of Home Affairs. It is more than one man can do.
- Every Minister is overburdened.

talker.party: ALP; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, William
Mr LAIRD SMITH

talk.start.para: - What does the honorable member suggest?

- Having launched upon the building of the Federal Capital - and it is one of the biggest enterprises that we have in hand - we should take care that the work is done properly, and surrounded with every essential to efficiency and success. I do not think that one Minister, or a Department having its head office in Melbourne, can undertake to carry out the supervision of that great enterprise so far removed as it is from the Seat of Government. I think the time has arrived when we should seriously consider whether the carrying out of the works connected with the Federal Capital ought not to be placed in the hands of an independent Commission. The InterState Commission, when created, might be intrusted with a portion of the responsibility; but, in any case, we should have some Board or Commission like the Railway Commissioners of the several States to deal with our great public works. It is impossible that the present system should be tolerated much longer. It is impossible for the Minister of Home Affairs to look after these great works, involving the expenditure of millions of money. We are just npw commencing expenditure in connexion with the Federal Capital, the transcontinental railway, and Northern Territory, and it would be money well spent to call into existence a Public Works Commission, authorized to supervise these great undertakings, and instructed, as are the Railway Commissioners of the different States, to carry them out on business principles, and as directed by Parliament, to the best advantage, free from all political influence. Once a work is approved by Parliament, those charged with carrying it out should be freed from all political influence, dictation, or interference. No Minister or member of Parliament should be allowed to send letters, or give instructions, to those intrusted with the carrying out of these great works to put on men who might not be able to pass an examination or test as to their fitness. Such a regulation would relieve members of Parliament and Ministers of a very great deal of trouble. I know, from my own experience in the State Parliament of Victoria, that one of the greatest worries of public life was the difficulty of dealing with a number of deserving persons who were in search of work. Naturally an honorable member would feel inclined vo do what he could to assist persons residing in his electorate to secure work, and it. might happen in such circumstances that the best men were not always employed in the Government Service. Conditions should be imposed which should secure the employment of the best men available for any work undertaken. This should apply, not only to permanent employes of the Government, but to casual employes also. Every man in Australia should be afforded the opportunity to comply with the necessary test to secure his employment as a permanent or temporary servant of the public, without fear, favour, or affection. If, when we launch these great Commonwealth undertakings, employment upon them is only to be obtained through political influence and favoritism, there will be a carnival - I will not say of political corruption -but of errors and disasters which will recoil upon those who are responsible for it. I should be very sorry to see our Federal institutions disgraced by any such disaster. We are all concerned in the success of these great enterprises, and in seeing that there shall be no disgrace brought upon Federal institutions through the employment of labour as the result of political influence, mainly of the dominant majority.
- I have given my pledge to the country that every work we undertake shall be tested and compared with work of the same kind done by private persons.
- There is only one way in which to carry out such a promise, and that is to see that the best labour is employed.
- All our factories are required to keep careful accounts of all work done in them.
- I ask the Prime Minister and the Minister of Home Affairs whether they will inquire into these charges in connexion with the Federal Capital to begin with?
- I have done so.
- They are made by the Builders and Contractors Journal.

- They are made upon the authority of men who apparently were at the place, and saw what they complained of. They are made in a public journal, and it is of no use to say that we may ignore such criticism. It is of no use for honorable members opposite to follow the example of the ostrich and, burying their heads in the sand, say "It is all right, there is nothing in them." There are the charges and the proof, and we should have some inquiry.
- There is no proof, but perhaps some evidence of what is complained of.

- There is what is known in law as prima facie evidence that something is wrong, and the matter should be looked into. We should know upon what conditions men have been employed at the Federal Capital, ana" whether only New South Wales men are employed there.
- The Minister of Home Affairs will tell the honorable member all that.
- Why should only men from one Slate be employed there?
- What odds if they are all New South Wales men?

- We are dealing with national works in national territory, and men in all the States should have an equal chance of employment upon them. Every Australian citizen should have a fair chance to secure employment in connexion with the building of the Federal Capital. The work should not be confined to the residents of any one State. There should be a central registry for employment established, where men desiring employment in connexion with these undertakings could lie registered and given an opportunity, in their turn, to pass any test required to secure employment. I have dealt with the charges made in connexion with the work at the Federal Capital, and have shown that complaints of the kind referred to are not confined to one journal. I come now to the charges made in the Melbourne Argus, and I direct the attention of the Prime Minister and his colleagues to the fact that two or three serious charges have been formulated in a circumstantial manner. I need read only one paragraph from the Argus to indicate the circumstantial character of the charges -

quote.para: It may bc noted that as far back as February last the inspectors wrote asking the Postmaster-General to receive them as a deputation, in order that they might reilly to certain charges formulated against them by a deputation of the men.

speech.para: There «is on the face of it prima facie evidence of a substratum of truth as the basis of a charge so circumstantially made. I ask the Prime Minister to bring this under the notice of his colleague the Postmaster-General, and see whether the inspectors have been complaining of want of discipline on the part of the men employed in carrying out postal work. Let him ask whether they have been reporting some of the men for refusing to obey orders, and whether they have complained that they have been unable to get them suspended or dismissed

The Prime Minister very properly said just now that men in the Public Service who would not do their duty should be dismissed. That is quite right, and I ask. the right honorable gentleman if he will now inquire whether the inspectors have reported men for having refused to do their duty and for having been insubordinate and insolent ?

talk.start.para: - The honorable ' member's time has expired.

. - I agree with 'those honorable members who complain of the non-expenditure of sums voted on the Estimates, but I realize that it may be impossible for a Minister to expend in the financial year the whole of the money allocated to particular works. Circumstances may arise to prevent the work being carried out as expeditiously as was expected, such as unprecedented rains, and so forth ; but, wherever possible, it should be the aim of the Government to see that the votes are expended. I am chiefly concerned with the expenditure in the Postal Department. The Government have done well in placing considerable sums of money at the disposal of the Department in order to provide additional facilities for those who reside in country districts; and I trust that the responsible Minister will exercise all the power he has with a view to seeing that this money is expended in the way intended. Much has been done, but much remains yet to be done; and I feel sure that' the Government will do their utmost to provide the necessary additional facilities. I am pleased to see that the Government recognise the necessity of doing something for the poorly-paid officials in allowance offices, and have allocated a sum of money to that end.. There are some works that personally I am not at all anxious to see hurriedly carried out. On the military side, I think we are, perhaps, going a little too fast. There may be justification for some of the heavy expenditure that is being incurred, but I notice that, on the Military College it is proposed to spend £113,000, and on the Naval College £73.000.
- The Military College is only a temporary building.

- It is a large sum of money, and I am doubtful whether we are justified in the expenditure, especially if the building is of a temporary character. We have to find all this money out of revenue ; and if we set ourselves the task of. following out a certain scheme, which involves additional expenditure every year, I am afraid that, in the next two or three years, we shall have taken up more than we can carry. I should, therefore, like to see the Government exercise the pruning knife as much as possible. I may say that I thoroughly approve of carrying out Government works by means of day labour. It is, of course, necessary that criticism should be launched against the proposals of the 'Government, but I deprecate criticism such as that we heard this afternoon from the honorable member for Wakefield. The Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, and the honorable member for Bendigo gave us fair criticism ; but the honorable member for Wakefield went to extremes. I take it that the people of Australia, who returned us here to represent them, require us to carefully and calmly review any proposed expenditure, and place our views dispassionately before the country. The honorable member for Wakefield, however, went so far as to say that the day-labour system was costing 50 to 100 per cent, more than would the contract system ; and he ought to have offered some justification for the statement.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - I said that some of the work carried out under the day-labour system was costing that much more.

- The honorable member, when challenged, failed to justify his statement ; and yet he asked this House to institute an inquiry. If we are to have an inquiry every time a little criticism is launched against the expenditure of a particular Department, or against the working of any part of the governmental machine, we shall cause considerable expense to the taxpayers, for no one can tell where we shall end if we are called upon to deal with alleged charges. If there is one scintilla of justification for the charge that men are loafing, a strict inquiry should be made, and it can best be made, not by a Select Committee, but by the responsible Minister, who can call for reports from officers in whom he has complete confidence. If any of the employes are found malingering, it is the Minister's duty to take the necessary steps to clear out those who are guilty. I cannot see why works which can be carried out with success by means of contract, cannot be carried out with equal success by means of day labour. A contractor must employ men in whom he has confidence to see that the work is properly performed, and the same can be done in the Commonwealth service. What is to prevent the Government from appointing men equally capable with those who are appointed by contractors, and thus insuring that the work is done on fair lines as between employer and employed? All men should have a fair day's wage for a fair day's work. The honorable member for Wakefield, without offering any proof whatever, said that Mr. Griffith, the Minister of Works in New South Wales, had already spoken eloquently against the system of day labour. I have read most of Mr. Griffith's statements, but I have never seen him yet condemn the day-labour system ; in fact, he has said that it is a success. Only recently, he instanced the State brickworks, and the Kiama quarry as successes ; and all that Mr. Griffith is doing is to introduce, side by side with day labour, a system of paying a percentage of 5 to per cent, to the man in charge of the work on its- cost in accordance with their tender.
- Mr. Griffith is complaining of the same thing that has been complained of here to-day.

- Mr. Griffith is making a test in the way I have indicated ; but I do not agree with his action. If we introduce a system of giving a percentage to the man in charge, over and above the estimated cost, we shall, I am afraid, have scamped work with a view to speed and the bonus, irrespective of quality. I see no need for any plan except that of employing competent men as overseers, whose duty it should be to see that the work is fairly and squarely, performed as between the Government and the employe. I do not believe in any man being rushed ; but, as I say, all should have a fair day's pay for fair day's work. The honorable member for Bendigo has told us that in certain respects he believes in day labour, while in other respects contract labour is the better; but, personally, I believe iri clay labour all round. Contractors in various parts of Australia have in the past made huge fortunes out of Government contracts ; and surely the Commonwealth, or any other Government, can carry out the work just as well, and allow the people, as a whole, to have the benefit of the money thus saved? After ;ill it is the men employed upon these works who have to make a profit for the Commonwealth. I was very pleased to hear the Prime Minister say that he believed in the system of day labour being properly carried out, that he believed in having officers to superintend operations with a view to seeing that justice was done between man and man, and between the employes and the people of the Commonwealth. Under such conditions there can be no reason for the failure of that system.
- Is it done at the present time?
- I believe that it is. I take it that the Minister will make proper inquiries into the charges which have been made by the Argus newspaper.
- He cannot get the necessary information.

- If one of our daily newspapers can obtain information of sufficient importance to warrant it in making such grave accusations, surely the Minister will experience no difficulty in ascertaining the true position. If his officers report that conditions are not what they ought to be, it will be his duty- to make a change. As far as the great body of men employed in our public Departments are concerned, I hold that they are good men. I do not believe that there is a scintilla of justification for the charges which have been hurled against the employes under our' day-labour system. My own opinion is that they spring from political bias. In regard to certain works which are in progress in the Federal Territory, the contractors realize that they have been driven to their last ditch, and consequently they will neglect no opportunity of ridiculing the day-labour system with a view to rendering it unpopular. If the Government do their duty they will have an inquiry conducted into the works which are being carried out by them. There can only be one man responsible for any shortcomings on the part of the employes, and that is the officer who is in charge of any particular work. If he fails to do his duty he should be dealt with. The officers in charge of our public undertakings should see that fair value is received for the wages which are paid. If there were anything to justify ail inquiry being made into the methods which are being pursued upon our public works outside of what I have suggested, 1' should unhesitatingly favour the adoption of that course. But if we were to take notice of every statement which is published in the press, and to investigate its truth and falsity, there would be no end to our inquiries. It frequently happens that these statements are made by irresponsible persons. Some honorable members have contended that the time has arrived when we ought to appoint a Public Works Committee upon the lines of the New South

speech.para: Wales Public Works Committee. Personally, I do not think that it has. I fail to» see what works we could remit to such as body. If we are going to refer to a Public Works Committee every Commonwealth1 work which involves an expenditure of more than £20,000, the result will be an endless* waste of time. The Committee would have to visit various parts of Australia, and the chances are that twelve months would, elapse before it arrived at a decision in regard to any particular undertaking. In New South Wales the position is very different. Our engineers and surveyors have* already reported upon the transcontinental railway, and a similar remark is applicable to the proposed line from Oodnadatta to Pine Creek. We are practically committed to that undertaking. If the project were referred to a Public Works Committee that body would visit all the State capitals and the Northern Territory, and its inquiry would probably extend over a period of two years. Such a- course of action is entirely unnecessary- Does anybody seriously suggest that works in the Federal Territory, involving am expenditure of more than £20,000, should' be delayed pending the decision of a Public Works Committee? We have heard a good deal about the cost of day labour ,as compared with the contract system, and yet it is now suggested that we should appoint a. Public Works Committee under which considerable cost would be heaped up without any justification. There is all the difference in the world between the position of New South Wales and that of the Commonwealth. We have to deal only with the Northern Territory and the Federal Capital . Already we have a design for the Federal City, and when once Parliament decides that a public building shall be erected there, we shall merely have to determine its location. If such a project were remitted to a Public Works Committee delay would be inevitable. It has been urged that under that system we should exercise control over the expenditure. As a matter of fact we should exercise no control whatever.

talk.start.para: - We should have an idea of whether a work was justifiable or not?

- We should not. Nobody will say that the public buildings in the Federal Territory are not necessary. We know that most of them are required' within a certain time. I take it that the design of the Capital City which has been, approved will assist us to decide where- those buildings should be located. Consequently, there is no necessity for the appointment of a Public Works Committee. If such a body were appointed, it would have no control whatever over the expenditure, because it would merely recommend whether it was desirable to undertake a public work or not. Parliament would then be called upon to approve or disapprove that work, and if it were approved, the Minister of Home Affairs would have control of it just as he has to-day. I believe that the day-labour system has come to stay, and that any comparison between it and the contract system will work out in its favour. In New South Wales the Railway Commissioner has been carrying out a lot of work by day labour, and up till twelve months ago - I have not the later figures - it was conclusively proved that that system was cheaper than was the contract system. The result has been that almost the whole of the railways constructed there have been carried out by means of day labour.
- Plenty of private firms are using the day-labour system on their own buildings.

- Exactly. Under proper supervision better work is obtained under that system than under the contract system, and without any additional expenditure. The Minister can make the necessary inquiries, and, if he finds any grounds for the statements made from time to time in regard to the system, he should take proper means to have any mistakes or abuses rectified, and see that the system is given a fair and square trial. If he does that, I shall feel quite satisfied as to the result.

.- The honorable member for Hunter has assumed, I think quite in error, that the discussion initiated by the honorable member for Dalley hinges upon the question of contract versus day labour, but he has introduced quite a new phase, I think. The honorable member for Dalley, in commencing this interesting debate-
- He did not commence it.

- I think that he struck the note which sounded throughout this chamber in a very wholesome fashion indeed, and I have to compliment him upon the courage with which he rose to speak in the way he did.
- You have to compliment the honorable member for Herbert, as well.

- I have had some experience of what it is to stand up in a party, most of them hostile in regard to a particular point, and to speak one's opinion freely on a question before the House. The honorable member for Dalley pointed out that this was not an ordinary charge, not a mere casual criticism that appears day by day and week by week in an ordinary newspaper, but a much more serious matter. Any honorable member with a sense of proportion must realize that the 'charge which was made in the Argus, and indicated by the honorable member for Dalley, is of a kind which no Government with any regard for its own credit can afford to ignore. It is all very well for the Minister of Home Affairs, in the belief that he has an unbreakable phalanx behind him, to pooh-pooh any inquiries in connexion with matters of which he has charge, or to refuse to give information which honorable members are perfectly entitled to get, but it is quite another thing for the Minister to say, " We are going to take no notice of such charges, and we refuse to see anything in them." The charge indicated here by the honorable member for Dalley is a definite one. We all know - and I think that many honorable members on the other side have an uneasy feeling in this connexion - that public work under this Government is not' being carried on in the way in which it ought to be. No one can go about with his eyes and ears open without being made aware of the fact that there is a good deal of manipulation of work which is not altogether in the interests of the country. The honorable member for Herbert spoke of the necessity for supervision in carrying out public works. There is no doubt that with day labour effective supervision is required ; but something more is wanted. The honorable member pointed out that when he was supervising certain works he was able to say, " I do not care anything for the Minister or for the Government. I am here in a position which requires me to perform certain duties, and those duties I intend to perform." Is that the position with regard to the supervision of Commonwealth work at present? Is it not a fact that at least the Minister of Home Affairs goes over the heads of the responsible officers of his Department, and does things without consideration for them, and without consulting them? Is not that a state of affairs likely to bring about a good deal of demoralization? Is it likely that supervisors or inspectors will assert themselves as they should do when they know that perhaps the men can go past them and get the ear of the Minister in a way which they cannot hope to do, and that they will not get thanked even for the pains which they take in the interests of the public? I have information that that state of affairs is going on in connexion with public works.
- Why do you not let the Minister know of it?
- I have already instanced one case, and I think that the honorable member knows what the attitude of the Minister is towards that.
- The Chinn case?

- I think there are more cases than one which could be brought forward if we had a proper inquiry. The honorable member for Wakefield is accused of making charges which he refuses to prove in the House. I do not think it is reasonable to expect him to do that here.
- He was asked to make a specific charge.

- What the honorable member for Wakefield asked for, and what I asked for. is a Committee of Inquiry, composed of men with expert knowledge, who would be independent of any political influences, and have power to go into all matters thoroughly. There is a good deal of evidence which could be laid before such a body, but which we cannot give utterance to even in this chamber.
- You ought to make out a -prima facie case, though.

- With all respect to the honorable member, I think that a prima facie case has been made out. We have had certain statements made, which are alleged to be statements of fact, and it is for the Government either to refute them or to give an opportunity for them to be probed.
- There has not been one specific charge made in the chamber to-day.

- I, for one, do not propose to make any specific charges in this connexion; but I know that there is room for a great deal of inquiry. That is what we demand, and what the Government, I think, in all reason, ought to concede. In their own interests, they should make an inquiry, because, if they stand up in the attitude of the Minister of Home Affairs, jeering and sneering at any suggestion of this kind, they may rest assured that a strong suspicion will be created in the public mind that there is something which makes them afraid to grant an inquiry. The best thing they can do, I think, is to accept the suggestion of the honorable member for Dalley in the spirit in which it was made, and satisfy the country as to whether these charges are groundless or well-founded.

speech.para: Almost every year I have had a grumble at a matter to which nearly every honorable member lias referred in connexion with the Works Estimates, and that is the re-voting of sums. I do not want to accuse the Government in this respect, because re-voting has been chronic since the inception of Federation. It is rather a defect of the system under which we are working than a thing which could be laid to the charge of any Government. I notice, however, that there is a greater tendency towards re-voting with some of the States than with others. Apparently in some States the works are carried out much more thoroughly and much more expeditiously than in other States. Western Australia seems to be one of the worst off of the States in this respect.

talk.start.para: - - -It is a very slow place.

- It is not a very slow place, as the honorable member will find if he takes the trouble to pay us a visit.
