I can assure him that we shall be able to satisfy, him that it is one of the most up-to-date and most live States in the Commonwealth. There is something wrong with the system of carrying out works in Western Australia for which moneys are voted. I want the Government to ascertain if there is a defect which operates to the disadvantage of Western Australia even more than it appears to do in regard to some of the other States.

speech.para: Mr.- West. - Perhaps the State might have better members.

talk.start.para: - Some of the States have a greater number of members. I do not know that quantity means .quality, but, no doubt, in politics there is great virtue in numbers.

speech.para: Although we have been told that a grand up-to-date post-office is to be erected in Perth, the sum made available for the work this year is only £5,000. A much larger sum might reasonably have been provided for the year's expenditure. I noticed a short time ago that some of those who have properties on the site of this building were making improvements of a somewhat permanent character. That does not indicate a desire on the part of the Government to hurry on the work. In view of the character of the building, .£5,000 is a ridiculously small amount to provide for expenditure upon it in twelve months, and I should like some explanation from the Minister as to whether this is all that will be spent during the current financial- year. If so, and the annual expenditure is to continue at this rate, it will be a good many years before the post-office is an accomplished fact.

There is a good deal to recommend the establishment of a Public Works Committee as suggested by some honorable members. Such a Committee would have to be a modification of the body existing in New South Wales. It would have to take over some of the responsibility of the Minister of Home Affairs, who is at present overburdened with the multitude of details that have to be' attended to.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - Such a Committee would give Parliament opportunities for knowing what is going on.
- It would be the medium through which Parliament would be kept informed of the work of the Department.
- It would practically mean having six Ministers instead of one.

- A Committee could do much of the work for which the Minister has not time. To my mind, it is not the duty of the Minister to attend personally to the numerous details connected with such a work as the construction of the transcontinental railway, for instance. A Public Works Committee would attend to a vast amount of detail, and would give to the Parliament more information than is at present obtainable. A great deal of the work of the Imperial Parliament is done by Committees, which supplement the work of Ministers, and enable the Houses to keep in better touch with the multifarious details of what I may call sub-administration than is possible under our system.
- It is the same in the United States of America.

- That may be so. Here we boggle along very much in the dark regarding public works under construction. The Minister has introduced an innovation of some value in a circular that he issues to members monthly. That enables us to keep in touch, in some degree, with what is taking place in his Department, but even he will admit that we get only a vague and general idea from it of the work that is being done. I do not suggest that there should be a great amount of printing, but a Committee would always be in a position to throw a flood of light on any question of construction or expenditure.
- Or material used.

- Yes. The Prime Minister has given us to understand that he has introduced a system by which we can know exactly how much is spent on every public work. I hope that that method of bookkeeping will be generally followed.
- It has been made the rule in regard to all our factories. Absolute debit and credit accounts must be kept.
- The same thing should be done in regard to all public works, such as the undergrounding of telephone wires, for example.
- It is done in regard to the construction of the building now being erected at the back of the Treasury.

- There should be an estimate made of the value of every work proposed. It is surprising how near an expert can get to the actual cost of a work by estimating it in advance. Given definite rates of wages - which should be possible under this Government - he can tell within a small fraction what a work will cost. Such an estimate ought to be made in connexion with every public work.
- It is done.
- The, estimates ought to be put on record, and with them statements ' of the actual cost incurred, so that honorable members may know whether the cost of a work has exceeded the estimate.
- That is done now.
- I am glad to hear it. I suggest that the information should be made available to honorable members who desire it.

talker.party: ANTI-SOC; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; LP from 1922; NAT from 1925
talker.name: FOSTER, Richard
Mr RICHARD FOSTER

talk.start.para: - Why not allow a Committee to examine the records ?
- Honorable members can obtain any information they desire from the Treasury.

- A Works Committee that would supervise expenditure would be a good innovation. Although the Prime Minister tells us that we can get from the Treasury all the information we require, I have found it difficult to obtain anything like detailed information regarding many Government works, and, no doubt, other honorable members have been in the same position. I hope that the result of the debate will be improved methods of dealing with public works, and thus a better, more efficient and economical service, together with a system which will enable honorable members to know exactly what is being done-

.- I have been greatly surprised at times at the tone of this debate. A comparatively new member myself, I have heard old parliamentarians complaining about not being able to get information which I have great ease in obtaining on making inquiries at the Departments. Whenever my request for information has been legitimate and reasonable, it has never been denied or refused by a Minister or by officers. I take it that if other honorable members are prepared to show the same energy, they will be placed in exactly the same position as I am. The day-labour question is not a new matter. It is an old friend, and is often brought up simply for party purposes. It has been raised in connexion with nearly every Department that has been run by the State of Victoria. If any State has been subject to criticism on account of it, Victoria, has been, especially in regard to the Newport Workshops. The statement was made over and over again, that, owing to Government supervision and the Government stroke, the action of the Government in taking full charge of the construction of locomotives for the Victorian railways was costing the taxpayers a considerable sum: but investigations made by a/i independent tribunal proved that the locomotives and other machinery were being turned out at the Government workshops at a far cheaper rate than any private individual could possibly do the work for. I regret to have to stale that trie Government of Victoria have been, in recent years, so short-sighted as to permit to be sent out of the country a large amount of work which should have teen carried out in our own workshops. The Victorian taxpayers are losing to-day no less than £150,000 through the action of the Government in sending for engines outside of Australia. That amount of money could have been saved if the engines had been made in the Government workshops.
- The money could be kept in the country.

- And the money could be kept- in the country as well. The whole thing is a scandal. It arose simply because certain officials have a tendency to discover, all of a sudden, that they require certain things constructed, allow too limited a time for local people to put in a tender, and then make that an excuse for going beyond the bounds of the Commonwealth in. order to get what is wanted. I hope and trust that the present Government will not be guilty of sending out of Australia for machinery and materials that could be made in Australia by our own workmen. I gather that some dredges are to be obtained by the Defence Department, I presume, to deepen She approaches to naval bases. I understand - and I hope that the Minister who represents the Minister of Defence in this Chamber will take note of this matter - that in connexion with those dredges the officials of the Defence Department - I presume the information refers to them - are allowing too limited a time for Australian manufacturers to tender for the work of making the dredges in Australia. I believe I am only one of many members on both sides of the House who will resent the sending out of Australia of work which can be done here; and I sincerely hope that those dredges, and anything else that we can make for any Government Department, will be made in Australia.

talker.party: LP; NAT from 1917
talker.name: MASSY-GREENE, Walter
Mr MASSY-GREENE

talk.start.para: - The Prime Minister promised that the Government would have the dredges made in Australia.

- At any rate, the complaint has already been made to- me - and it was mentioned to me again as recently as last night - that Australian tenderers are being allowed too short a time to draw up specifications, and put in their tenders for the dredges.
- That seems a strange position. If tenderers in other parts of the world are given sufficient time to tender, surely those in Australia are being allowed sufficient.

- The Honorary Minister knows that' when questions have been, put in the House on the subject, the invariable reply has been that the "articles were required in a hurry, and that local tendererscould not comply - with the conditions. Surely, when we know what is required, we ought to give local makers ample opportunity to put in tenders for the work, and,, what is more, to secure it, and have it done by Australian workmen. I take it that the Government are pledged to that principle, and, so far :is I am concerned, if I find1 that the work of constructing many more things is sent out of the Commonwealth, I shall feel that it is time for some one to move the adjournment of the House, and have a full-dress debate on the matter. I resent work being sent out of the Commonwealth that ought to be done here.
- Cheer up !

- I am a little vigorous on this point, because I feel strongly about it. I do riot care in what State the work is done, so 'long as it is done in Australia by Australian workmen. We can do the work here, and why should it be sent out of Australia, and our men be allowed to walk the streets?
- We purpose sharing the work all round the States.

- That will be a good thing. So far as day labour is concerned, whenever I have found that complaints have been going round, and whenever I have had an idea that the correct thing was not being done towards the Government by any man or set of men, I have at once made inquiries at the Department which has charge of the work in question. I have also made very full inquiries with regard to the relative merits of contract work and day labour, as ascertained by the experience of the officers of the Home Affairs Department. I am in a position to state that many of our rifle butts are being constructed at half the cost that used to be incurred under the contract system. I also know that work which has been done at the forts in Victoria and the other States has been better and more cheaply done by day labour than under the old contract system.
- My trouble is that 1 cannot find any rifle ranges being constructed at all.

- Any requests by country members for necessary works, especially for increased telephonic, telegraphic, and postal facilities, will always have my hearty support. If we are to have people settled in the country, we shall have to make country life more attractive than it is at present. I believe it will be found, when the splendid work that is being put into the new Treasury Buildings for the Commonwealth is completed, that the .day-labour system has paid the Commonwealth better than if the work had been let by contract. With day labour there is no inducement to " scamp " the work. Every man is supposed to put in the best that is in him. I do not think any member on either side of the House is prepared to advocate that the waster, or the man who desires to loaf on his job - or on his fellow-worker on any work - should be engaged on Government or any other work. I know that the officials hi the Home Affairs Department have said that they will not have men whom they do not consider competent to carry out the work intrusted to them. I believe that, as the result of the conditions that prevail, and the wages that are paid, we now have engaged on the various Commonwealth works men who are among the very best to be found in the States. Of course, mistakes will occur, and every man cannot be made to do exactly what we wish him to do. So far as I am concerned, I favour a fair day's work for a fair day's pay. I do not believe in a nigger-driving system. No Britisher ever responds willingly to treatment of that kind. But if you treat a man properly, he will respond in the proper spirit. I have had some experience of the employment of labour - not much, I admit - and I always found that the result of treating men as they ought to be treated was that they responded handsomely and willingly. Employers of labour of considerable experience have testified to the same thing in my presence.

speech.para: Complaint has been made about the necessity for re-voting money for public works purposes, and that works, authorized last year have not been carried out within the specified time. The honorable member for Herbert referred to the fact that on the present occasion a considerable amount of money is being re-voted which ought to have been spent during the past financial year.

talk.start.para: - That kind of thing occurs every year.

- lt does; but if honorable members turn up the records they will find that the estimates for new public works were not introduced last year until 26th October. That means that the officers responsible for the expenditure of this money had less than nine months, instead of twelve, for the carrying out of the works. The same state of affairs ought not to prevail at the end of the current financial year.
- We are doing our best this session.

- I remember the promise made at the close of last session by the Postmaster-General. As large sums were voted for the purpose of new and ordinary services, the honorable gentleman promised that extra hands should be employed, in order that the works might be executed within the financial year. I, for one, must join in the complaint that has been made that some of these works have not been carried out. Again, we are called upon to re-vote sums of money which were voted last year. I hope that the same thing will not occur again, and that when the next. Estimates for works and buildings are under consideration, those of us who are here will be able to congratulate the Government on having carried out well and faithfully the works authorized by Parliament.
- The honorable member is getting a fine lot done in his constituency.

- If it were not for the works of a naval and military character that are to be executed in my electorate, not much would be done there. It appears to me that the naval and military officers can get almost anything they ask for.
- Worse luck.

- We may be going a little too fast in that direction. It is true that we must have defence as an insurance against aggression, and for the protection of the lives and property of the citizens of the Commonwealth. But I should be inclined to lessen the votes for naval and military purposes, if by so doing we could increase the amounts voted for post-offices, the construction of telephone lines, and other services useful to the community.
- Does the honorable member include rifle ranges?
- Yes, it is very desirable that rifle ranges should be constructed.

talker.party: ALP; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, William
Mr LAIRD SMITH

talk.start.para: - Or manoeuvre areas ?

- I am rather against the acquisition of land for that purpose. It appears to me that the Commonwealth Government are purchasing an enormous amount of property. They are purchasing manoeuvre areas in Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland, and Tasmania. What with the Northern Territory, the Federal Capital, and the purchases being made in this and other directions, the Commonwealth Government will soon be the owner of an immense amount of land in this country.

speech.para: Another topic that has been introduced in the course of the debate has reference to the appointment of a Public Works Committee. We have a Railways Standing Committee in Victoria, and a Public Works Committee in New South Wales. I am under the impression that like Committees have been appointed by other State Parliaments. But I am in agreement with the honorable member for Hunter in opposing this idea as far as the Commonwealth is concerned. Having regard to the great extent of Australia, and the fact that the Commonwealth has to carry out works in every part, it appears to me that if we appointed a 0Committee to look after the public works that are required north, south, east, and west, we should have to give leave of absence for a session or two to its members. They would seldom be here at all. Undoubtedly we have arrived at a difficulty in regard to public works. It is impossible for one Minister properly to supervise all the branches of the Service which are under the control of the Department of Home Affairs. In my opinion, the functions of the Department, will have to be divided. The work of the Minister should be shared by some other member of the Government - probably by an Honorary Minister. But to appoint a' Public WorksCommittee would be to establish an excrescence on this Parliament. There are too many excrescences in connexion with the State Parliaments, and I do not think that we require anything of the kind here.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable member think that the Victorian Standing Committee on Railways has been a success?
- Yes, but Victoria is a very small patch of Australia. What might be advisable in- Victoria or New South Wales is not even possible in regard to the whole Commonwealth of Australia.

talker.party: ALP; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, William
Mr LAIRD SMITH

talk.start.para: - Victoria is a very rich patch all the same.

- It is the richest patch in Australia. But a Public Works Committee would be found entirely unworkable when it was sought" to' apply it to the Commonwealth. At present we are overloading the Minister of Home Affairs. He has practically four Departments under his control. It is absolutely impossible for any one man to look after all these concerns with credit to himself and satisfaction to the country.
- The Minister has a good staff.
- I am glad that he lias, and his staff can, of course, help him considerably. But, nevertheless, the work is too much for one Minister to do.

speech.para: I am a. stickler for having everything, manufactured in Australia that can possibly be done here. I observe that- a number of boats are to be built for the Defence and Customs Departments. I hope that these vessels will be built in Australia. There are docks and ship-builders in Sydney and Melbourne who can carry out such works as well as they can be done in any part of the world. I trust, therefore, that the Government will not send the work out of the Commonwealth. I must compliment the Minister of Home Affairs on this as on other matters - that, notwithstanding that at times the strongest of pressure has been brought to bear upon him to give orders to foreign firms, he has resisted them, and insisted upon locally-made articles being used. The Government may have had to wait a little bit longer, and to pay a little more money for the things required, but it is a good policy. The Defence authorities ought to be compelled to do the same. Let them wait a little longer for what they require, and, if necessary, pay a little more, in order that » work may be done within the Commonwealth.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: . - While I sympathize cordially with the Minister of Home Affairs in having to bear the brunt of the attacks in connexion with a great deal of the expenditure proposed in the Works Estimates, I would remind him that he is singled out for this distinction because he happens to be the Minister in charge of the Department responsible for the spending of the money on public works. Criticism of the manner in which work is carried on must necessarily be brought under his notice. But it does not necessarily mean that the attacks are levelled against himself. That will be determined by his own attitude. The object of these criticisms is to bring matters under the notice of the Government in the hope that works will be carried out in a proper manner in the future. It is also hoped that if a certain section of workers have not been honestly doing a fair day's work, and that as a result of their slackness discredit has been brought upon the administration of the Department, steps will be taken to put an end to that state of affairs. I must compliment the honorable member for Hunter and the honorable member for Dalley on the speeches they have made in this connexion. It is a pleasure to the Opposition to hear such a healthy note being sounded occasionally from the Ministerial side of the House, and it inspires us with the belief that the ultimate regeneration of honorable members opposite may not be regarded as absolutely hopeless. As the discussion from the Ministerial side seems to have centered largely round the question of day versus contract labour, I may say at once that I have not heard any honorable member on this side of the House championing contract as against day labour, nor do I know that any member of the Opposition has a prejudice against day labour. All that we contend is that in connexion with public works that are carried out by day labour, the interests of the' public should be safeguarded by seeing that a fair day's work is given for the pay received out of the public funds. I am glad that at least some honorable members opposite are in agreement with us in this regard- It is a pleasure to listen to the honorable member for Hunter, because, when he rises to speak, he has generally something sensible to say to the House. As to the charges that have been made by the Argus, I would remind the Committee that it is not the business of the Opposition to try to prove them; it is their duty only to bring them under the notice of the Minister, and to ask that he shall look into them if he has not already done so. The suggestion made by the honorable member for Hunter, that the Minister should send his own officers to make a personal investigation of these works and to see that everything is proceeding satisfactorily, ought certainly to be adopted. It is all very well for the Minister to say that the charges are false ; but we have to remember that they are not made by an irresponsible journal. The instances cited are so specific in character and so circumstantial in their nature as to suggest that information has been obtained from inside departmental sources, and that they have not been put forward merely as kites flown for the purpose of eliciting information, and on the off chance that something may be wrong. We see in the newspapers day after day letters drawing attention to the same sort of thing, and inviting Ministers to inspect specific works detailed in those letters. In view of all these circumstances there is reasonable ground for an investigation by an unbiased non-political committee if the Minister himself is not prepared to make a personal inquiry. Such an investigation should be made in the interests of honest workmen employed by the Commonwealth. I am not one of those who oppose day labour, nor am I prepared to believe all that contractors are prepared to say about day labourers. We know that there is a certain element of self-interest behind a great deal that may be said on that side, but making due allowance for exaggerations that may be prompted by sel f - interest, it seems to me that these statements, made by one of the most responsible newspapers in Australia, are of such a. serious character that they cannot be made light of. Coming from such a source, the least the Government can do to clear the atmosphere, and also to remove any stigma that may rest upon honest workmen, is to appoint a Committee to investigate the charges. If it is found that there are employed in connexion with Commonwealth works men who are not giving a fair return for the money they receive, they should be weeded out, and men who will be more honest in their service - any number of whom, I am sure, may be obtained in this country - should take their places. It is not fair to the great body of good men employed that they should have to suffer in repute through the few whose conduct has been made the subject of such strong press condemnation. That unsatisfactory workmen are employed, if not on Commonwealth works, at least in' connexion with State employment, is shown by certain action which has been taken by the Minister of Public Works for New South Wales, and what is happening in connexion with State employment may very reasonably be expected to occur in connexion with Commonwealth employment, unless proper supervision is enforced by the Minister standing behind his overseers. It is alleged, at all events by a responsible newspaper, that a certain measure of malingering, a certain amount of loafing, of drunkenness, and what is known as the ca'-canny system of working is going on, and it is reasonable to believe that there may be something in these charges. It is worth while quoting the following extract from an official letter which has been sent by Mr. W. J. Hannan, Under-Secretary of Works in New South Wales, on behalf of Mr. Griffith, Minister of Public Works, to the executive of different unions in that State -

quote.para: In a service such as the Public Service of this State - and " Commonwealth " might very well be substituted for the word " State" - carrying out large public works over an immense area, and employing large and increasing numbers of men, it must happen in the ordinary course of business that a considerable proportion of these will be found, from some cause or another, unsatisfactory, and bc removed from the service. In almost every case the workman so dismissed considers that he has a grievance, which he very properly brings before his union. Up to the present some of the unions have made it a practice, as a matter of course, to support the claim of their member so dismissed without serious investigation. It frequently happens that a workman is dismissed for carelessness or incompetency, and such workman's cause is championed by his union because lie happens to be a good fellow and a good unionist, whereas the Minister requires that he should be a good workman. The following facts are illustrative of the methods to which, in this regard, Mr. Griffith takes exception : - The secretary of a union telephoned to the Department, alleging that two of its members had been paid at a shilling per day below the proper rate. Inquiries were instituted, and papers hunted up. A long correspondence with the officer in charge of the work ensued, with the final result that it was ascertained that one of the two men was never employed on the works and the other had been paid the full rate. It is probable that, counting lengthy interviews between officers of the union and high-salaried officers of this Department, the time involved in making investigations and conducting correspondence, looking up documents and receipts, together with the amount paid for telegrams, the cost to the. State might have been anything up to ^50 for the investigation of what was, after all, a " mare's nest."

speech.para: That is a fairly strong indictment.

talker.party: ALP; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, William
Mr LAIRD SMITH

talk.start.para: - Does it not show that the Minister of Public Works in New South Wales is anxious that public works shall be carried out effectively?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - Certainly it does ; but it shows something more, too. It shows that all is not as it should be in connexion with State day-labour work, and there is need for Ministerial firmness. That is what is wanted here also. The point is that we have in this official letter the important admission by the Minister that the unions themselves are intervening for the purpose of securing the reinstatement of men who have been dismissed without taking the trouble to investigate such cases.

talker.party: ALP
talker.name: O'MALLEY, King
Mr KING O'MALLEY

talk.start.para: - They have never done it with me.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - This is a statement made, not by a newspaper or any irresponsible party outside, but oy the New South Wales Minister of Works. As a further example of what we may come to if this kind of thing is not Checked in the early stages of development, I may refer honorable members to the notorious Fitzroy dock scandal and to the Prince Alfred hospital scandal in New South Wales. As honorable members are no doubt aware, Royal Commissions had to be appointed to investigate some of these things. I. have before me the evidence taken by a Royal Commission that inquired into the Fitzroy dock scandal, and I warn the Minister of Home Affairs that what happened in that case may occur in connexion with Commonwealth public works if he is not very careful in the administration of his Department. We may yet be faced with scandals which may require investigations of a similar character. I quote the following -

quote.para: The evidence taken before the Royal Commission shows that on occasions when it has been necessary to reduce hands political influence has been used upon the Superintendents to reinstate men. " The office of Superintendent," says the official report, "is thus deprived of the dignity and respect which it should command from the workmen, and the Superintendent himself disheartened so that he ceases to urge necessary economies lest he should suffer further the humiliation of seeing his recommendations ignored."

speech.para: Here is a reference to a special case-

quote.para: A man named Sexton was sent away, and the Minister sent him back again. I think I sent him away twice, and the Minister sent him back.

talk.start.para: - What report is the honorable member quoting from?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - The report of the Royal Commission that inquired into the Fitzroy dock scandal. I do not say that we have reached such a state of affairs yet, but I am pointing out what may happen unless we are careful to nip this kind of thing in the bud if it is going on in connexion with Commonwealth works. I do not say that it is, but we hear references to it on the trams and in the trains, and, in addition, we have had a specific declaration on the subject on the authority of a reputable newspaper, which would not, I think, permit the use of its columns to lightly make unfounded charges of such a serious nature as those contained under the heading of " The Mail on the Job." To continue the quotation -

quote.para: The last time he came back he said, " Are you going to put me on again?" I said, "I cannot, in the face of the foreman's objection to you." He said, "You ought to; take that," handing me the Minister's order to put him on again.

speech.para: What the man handed to the superintendent was a letter from the Minister authorizing his reinstatement.

talk.start.para: - How long ago was this?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - Speaking from, memory, and subject to correction, I think it was when Mr. O'sullivan was Minister of Public Works in New South Wales. However, honorable members can look up the Commission's report for themselves. The evidence taken by the Commission shows what is possible under the day-labour system if it is not properly supervised. I do not say anything against the system. As a matter of fact, I am a firm believer in it, but with it there should be effective supervision. I realize that inspectors, foremen, and gangers may easily become unpopular by insisting upon men doing a fair day's work. Where there is even a small percentage of the men engaged upon a job who want to Iaaf, and an inspector, foreman, or ganger insists that they shall do as other , leil, . a fair day's work foc the wages paid then, the malcontents are likely to get such a man " set," to use a popular expression, and to give him a very uncomfortable time by processes which are very well known to my honorable friends opposite.
- Can the honorable member tell us, approximately, how many decades old his last quotation was ?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - It is only of comparatively recent date. Honorable members opposite have only to get a copy of the report of the Commission on the Fitzroy dock scandal to see for themselves what happened. I believe that the condition of things then existing has since been set right, but we do not want to develop that kind of thing in connexion with Commonwealth work, and in order to prevent it we should deal with it firmly at its very inception. We should let it be understood that while the Commonwealth Government are prepared to pay the highest wages for the work they require to be done, they will insist that a fair return shall be given for the money, which has- to come out of the taxpayers' pockets, and largely out of the pockets of the wage-earners themselves.- That must not be forgotten. Any loafing upon a Commonwealth work means a fraud upon fellow-workers, who have to find about 75 per cent, of the taxation out of which this money has to be paid. I pass now to the question of the building which is being erected for the Treasury Department in Melbourne. I have raised my voice before against what I consider wholly unwarrantable expenditure on buildings of a permanent character in Melbourne. We are spending huge sums of money, chiefly in Melbourne, which should be spent on permanent buildings of the same character in the Federal Territory. I say that the time is coming when it will be necessary for representatives of New South Wales, no matter on which side they sit, to band themselves together and stand up for the rights of the State under the Federal compact. I believe we shall have the support of some honorable members from the other States if we do so. Far too much money is being spent by the Commonwealth in Victoria, and particularly in Melbourne. I attribute this largely to the fact that the Federal Parliament meets in Melbourne, and the sooner we get away from the influence of Melbourne, its press, and politicians, and get into the Federal Capital, the better it will be for everybody concerned. We are spending hundreds of thousands of pounds here 011 ' the erection of buildings on enormously valuable sites, and every penny of the money should be spent on permanent buildings of a similar character in the Federal Capital. Why is it not done? Here we have a Minister of Home Affairs who says that he is no " rubber-stamp Minister." Let him show that he is not by insisting upon this money being spent where honorable members on both sides have declared over and over again it ought to be spent.

talker.party: ALP
talker.name: MOLONEY, Parker
Mr PARKER MOLONEY

talk.start.para: - What buildings is the honorable member referring to?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - The buildings for the Treasury Department and for other Departments, Woollen Mills, Clothing Factories, and others. I find that a further sum of £22,750 is to be voted in connexion with the building for the Commonwealth Treasurer in Melbourne.
- We must have these buildings in Melbourne, even after the Seat of Government is removed to the Federal Capital.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - I do not see that we shall need these' permanent buildings which are now being erected for the Commonwealth. We might do with buildings of a very much less pretentious character. We might hire, or even purchase, one large building, which I might mention if it were not for the fact that values might go up suddenly if I did, in which all the branch Federal offices might be established in Melbourne when the Seat of Government is removed to the Federal Capital. If the Minister is not going to spend money on the erection in the Federal Capital of buildings for the Federal Parliament and administrative offices, it is evident that the Parliament will continue for a prolonged period to meet in Melbourne, and that is not a desirable thing for the Federation. I cannot see how we are going to move at all, at the present rate of progress. I notice that for the Clothing Factory it is proposed to vote£7,000. Last year we were asked to vote £6,700 under this head, and a sum of £1,121 in excess of that has already been spent. Where are the honorable members and Ministers who indorsed the principle that these permanent institutions should, as far as practicable, be located in the Federal Territory? I further see that a sum of £8,000 is set down towards the acquisition of a site for the woollen mills.
- The sum is £15,000.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - I am speaking of the preliminary sums for works immediately proposed in these Estimates. The location of the mills is not mentioned specifically, but a search through the Estimates reveals the item buried under a generalizing heading. Perhaps the Minister will tell us whether this means the Geelong site? It is a crying shame that all this expenditure should be centered in Victoria, while, as soon as there is a mention of a vote for New South Wales, even if it be only for the construction of a dredge, the parish-pump type of Victorian politician is up in arms and talking about "the broad national view." We do not ask that money should be unfairly spent in New South Wales, but only that there should be a fair deal. The mills to which I have referred ought to be established in the Federal Territory, though, of course, not necessarily at Yass-Canberra. It has been said that the water supply there is not sufficient ; but the records of the gauges at the rivers are a sufficient contradiction. There is water in abundance over and above any claims that have been made in favour of the Federal Capital area. Then the Naval College has to be established at Geelong. Why this concentration of expenditure at Geelong? What has Geelong done that all these Commonwealth works should be concentrated there? We used to hear of Geelong as a very pleasant seaside village in which to spend a few hours; but lately it has been pushed into prominence in a way that necessarily attracts our attention and criticism, and there is every reason to believe that this lavish expenditure of public funds in the neighbourhood of Geelong is more political than otherwise. It is a remarkable fact, but whenever expenditure is proposed in New South Wales, we hear objections raised by Victorians, mostly in the Labour corner, but also in the Opposition corner. There is an awful outcry, and we are urged to take a " broad national view." Right! Let us do so; but we invariably find that this " broad national view " is bounded by Victoria. The " broad national outlook " of the honorable member for Corio is bounded by Corio Bay.
- Did I not offer the honorable member the military stables ?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - I do not know ; I am not after stables, but after justice for New South Wales and every part of Australia. Every State has a right to a fair deal, and every State should have the benefit of necessary expenditure. We ' must not distribute expenditure so as to inflict injustice on any section of the community ; and I am opposing these votes because I see that injustice is being done, not only to a State, a district, or the Federal Capital area, but to the country as a whole.
- Is there not a very good site for the woollen mills at Marrickville ?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - One of the best ; but I am not asking that the woollen mills should be established there - I am taking a "broad national outlook." I do happen to represent a district which is eminently suitable for the establishment of woollen mills, and where some of the finest woollen goods are manufactured - so good, indeed, are they, that they have a world-wide reputation. I am sufficiently patriotic, however, to recognise that we have a Federal Capital area common to all the States, an area which, though carved out of New South Wales, and ten times the size originally contemplated, has, with that generosity characteristic of its people, teen given cheerfully. I am merely urging that our Commonwealth Territory should have the benefit of the expenditure on these public works. I realize that, in any case, these works will have to be established in the Federal area, and that the present expenditure simply means duplication and waste. As showing the " broad national view " taken in Victoria, I may mention that a number of pettifogging municipal district bodies, of whom nobody ever heard before, are passing resolutions protesting against the Federal Capital being established in New South Wales, and against any further work being proceeded with in connexion with the Capital city. Those concerned in this agitation ask that there shall be a referendum ; but my reply is that a referendum was taken when the Constitution Bill was approved, and a solemn compact entered into with New South Wales. They are not prepared to honour the compact.

. - There may be an advantage in discussing the Works and Buildings Estimates as soon as possible after the delivery of the Budget, but one of the disadvantages attaching to the practice is that it induces honorable members to speak upon various items when, under other circumstances, they might not be disposed to do so. I recognise that, if we delay our criticisms upon these items until the Estimates-in-Chief are under consideration, we shall then be told that it is idle to talk about them, because the money has already been voted. But I rose, not to enter into an academic discussion upon the claims of New South Wales and Victoria, but to call attention to an item of £5i°0°: which I regret to see included in the Estimates for the Northern Territory. It reads : - " Railway construction survey from Pine Creek to Katherine. ' ' The amount involved is not a large one, but there is an old saying that a straw will show which way the wind blows. I take it that this item indicates that lt is the policy of the Government to start railway construction in the Territory at the Pine Creek end. T warn the Committee to act cautiously in this matter.' I protest against railway construction from the northern end of the Territory for several reasons. We shall be handicapped by the climate, by the tremendous expenditure which will be involved, by the difficulty of securing labour, and in many other directions. It is the duty of this Parliament to see that the Territory is opened up for development as quickly as possible. I recognise that the Commonwealth is rich, thanks to the prosperous seasons which it has enjoyed, but it is not so rich that we can afford to waste money. For that reason I protest against this vote, which means approving- of a policy which must involve an enormous expenditure. The development of the Northern Territory must come from the southern end. There are certain portions of Northern Australia - I suppose fully one-third of it - which are not more than 50 feet above sea-level. Any person with a grain of common sense must recognise that we cannot develop the Territory from those portions of it which are very little above sealevel.
- Or very little below it.
- There is not much of that country.

- Undoubtedly the higher lands of the Territory are located in the southern part of it, and not in the northern. We all know what are the conditions in Australia during the months of January and February. The settlement of the Territory must proceed from the southern portion of it, with the advent of the railway.
- Every other State has been developed from the coast.
- My honorable friend reminds me of the remark of

item.label: M.
item.para: Thiers, who, in speaking of the Bourbon princes, said " they had forgot nothing and learned nothing."

talk.start.para: - That does not answer my interjection. '

- Because, sixty or seventy years ago our forebears landed in Australia from light-draught vessels, and settled in spots which commended themselves to their judgment, is that any reason why we should not profit by their experience? I admit that the amount involved in this particular vote is not a large one.
- How much ?
- That is too much.

- I am not complaining of the amount, but I object to the Committee being pledged to a particular policy in this way. I wish now to call attention to the question of the Federal Capital. We are not spending much money in that direction. I am not interested in the question of Victoria versus New South Wales in regard to the site of the Federal Capital, but I think that no harm would be done if we did not spend any money there for the next ten years. There is one thing to which we are pledged by the Constitution, and that is that the Capital of the Commonwealth shall be in New South Wales. I ask any member of this House if, in their treatment of the Federal Government, the policy of the Sydney Government, whether Labour or Conservative, has not been most niggardly ?
- Not so far as land for the Capital is concerned.

- I do not know so much about that. I do not charge the people of New South Wales with approving of a niggardly policy towards the Commonwealth, but undoubtedly the policy of the New South Wales Government is that the Federal Capital shall be a second or third-rate city, for fear that it might become a rival of Sydney. It is an historic fact that the State Righters, not of New South Wales only, but throughout the Commonwealth, are the enemies of the Federal Government and this Parliament. In regard to the Federal Capital, there is no difference in New South Wales between a Labour and a Liberal Government. I feel absolutely certain that the feeling of the masses of the people of Australia is that, for a couple of generations, the seat of Government should be alternately in Melbourne and Sydney for ten years. The people of this generation are not fit to deal with this question. The State Righters' brigade is so strong, so prejudiced, and so bitter against the Federal system of government that whatever we may do in this generation we cannot do justice to building up the Federal Capital.
- The people will not stand that for long, though.

- The people of this generation cannot get out of their environment, but their children and grandchildren will grow up in a different environment, and when this bitter hatred of the Federal system has died down we shall find a Government existing in Sydney, and probably in Melbourne too, which will be prepared to deal justly and generously with the rights and the aspirations of the people of Australia. We ought to have a Federal Capital, but it should be one worthy of the Australian people. I am sorry to say that we are all more or less under the influence of the embittered feeling that obtains to-day, and are, therefore, not competent to deal with this question as it should be dealt with. I do not wish to refer to other items. These are two items for which I do not wish to vote any money, and, therefore, I thought it my duty to the Committee and the country to state as early as possible my reasons for holding the strong views that I do.

.- There appears to me, from the experience of the past, to be no justification for assuming that, although £20,500,000 is set down as the estimated expenditure for the current year, that amount will not be very seriously increased. When I refer to the Estimates for 1911-12, I find that of the total appropriation of £19,515,000, £1,105,684 was not expended, while the actual expenditure for the year was £20,546,361, so that the expenditure for last year, without appropriation, was £2,137,045. If that was the case last year, there is no reason to suppose that there may not be a very considerable sum expended in excess of the £20,500,000 which is provided for in these Estimates. With regard to the Northern Territory, there is an important fact to consider, and that is that up to the present time its population has been a diminishing nne. Owing to the strenuous efforts of South Australia some years ago, there was a considerable number of people located in the Northern Territory, but, according to Knibbs, this year there is an excess of deaths over births and of departures over arrivals. In view of this fact, it does seem to me that we are asked to sanction the expenditure of a very large amount, not on works which may be regarded as necessary for developmental purposes, but on works which are more or less of a fanciful nature, such as the following items, the first of which is, perhaps, the least objectionable of the lot : - Additions to Darwin Hospital, £1,650 ; houses for Government employés, £21,000 ; railway and construction survey from Pine Creek to Katherine, £4,200; erection and equipment steam laundry, £1,000; new court-house and warden's office, Pine Creek, £6,000 ; public works store, £4,000 ; and additional office accommodation, £4,000.I might go through the rest of the items, but shall content myself with calling the attention of the Committee to the meagre population of the Territory. If it justifies such items of expenditure as appear on these Estimates I have no common sense at all. In 1910 the population comprised 729 males, 166 females, and 157 children. The proposed expenditure is altogether out of proportion to the condition of things existing in the Northern Territory. The proposed expenditure on new works in the current year is £58,540.
- Is not that enough?

- We should first be assured that we are likely to get a considerable population before we expend a large sum on such a work as the erection and equipment of a steam laundry. I do nor know why a steam laundry is wanted when the population is so small. Cleanliness is next to godliness, but I do not think that this expenditure is justified. The first need is a policy which will induce people to go to the Northern Territory. When there is population, it will be time enough to provide the necessaries and comforts required. To precede settlement by works of this character is to put on the people of Australia, and in particular on those in the eastern States, an unfair and unreasonable charge. The heavy expenditure on public works to which we are already committed should make us pause in regard to the Federal Capital. In this matter I am hopelessly out of touch with the honorable member for Lang. In my view, there is no justification for expenditure on the Federal Capital at present. There are railways, developmental works, and defence works to be undertaken, all of which mean immense expense, and will impose a very heavy per capita charge upon the people. We should, therefore, defer all superfluous expenditure.
- What State does the honorable member represent?

- I have the honour to represent Australia. An aspect of the question worthy of attention is this : These Estimates are the first to come before us since the Minister of Home Affairs published his determination to give preference to unionists. The preliminary work in connexion with the Federal Capital is controlled by the Minister. This is, therefore, a serious matter.

talker.party: ALP; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, William
Mr LAIRD SMITH

talk.start.para: - The honorable member's party in conference said that it was in favour of preference to unionists.

- I answer only for myself. To give preference to a section in the carrying out of national works is a sin against the community, and in giving preference to those of a certain political colour you of necessity exclude others who may perhaps number amongst them the best workers in the land.
- The others are certainly taxpayers.

- Yes. A man who had enough spirit to say that he would not swim with the stream unless he were convinced that it was going in the right direction would be likely to be a better man than another who would not struggle against it. That, however, is a debatable subject on which I shall not enter. So far as the Minister is concerned, the question is not whether the man applying for work is a good man, but whether he is a unionist.
- The honorable member is mistaken.

- Then has the Minister retreated from his position? Was his famous intimation in regard to preference to unionists merely a display of fireworks? I do not propose' to discuss the relative merits of the day-labour and contract systems, but the Committee is entitled to know from the Minister whether certain definite charges which have been made against his Department are or are not true. The honorable member for Bendigo referred to an article which has been published in the Argus under the heading, " The Man on the Job," and pointed out that it contains a succession of definite charges. If these charges can be met by the Home Affairs Department-
- The work referred to _ is not being carried out by the Home Affairs Department.
- Then the charges should be met by the Department concerned. This is one statement - and I am sorry that the Prime Minister is not present to hear it -

quote.para: Take, for instance, the case of a " man on the job who familiarly and apparently successfully wrote to the Prime Minister as " Dear Comrade," and signed himself " Fraternally yours," &c.

speech.para: If the right honorable gentleman were here he would be able to say whether he received such a letter.

talk.start.para: - He has denied it.
- That labourer is as good as the Prime Minister or any other man in Australia.

- There is fitness to be observed in all things, and while the employ£ as well as the employer has his rights, I take it that when the employer is the Prime Minister, he should be addressed with respect, and with a proper regard for his dignity.
- What is lacking in the word " comrade" ?
- I have heard a general officer appeal to his men as comrades.
- The quotation continues -

quote.para: This labourer took time off on one occasion to interview the Prime Minister. Mr. Fisher's secretary referred him to the Postmaster-General, but the man, replying that " the Postmaster-General was no use to him," insisted on seeing the Prime Minister. He saw him. Later on he turned up at the trench, with two other convivial spirits, so drunk that he fell into the trench. This incident was duly reported. But was the man discharged? Of course not. He was shifted on to another gang. Thus kindly do Ministerial comrades protect their fellows.

talk.start.para: - Does not the honorable member in Methodist prayer meetings call other people '"'brother'.'? There is no harm in it.
- I know the capability of the Minister for turning everything into ridicule.
- I am not doing so.

- No workman, unless sure of his ground, would approach the Prime Minister in that way. That man knew that, being of the same political kidney, and under the control of the unions, the Prime Minister was not free to dismiss him. The following definite statement is made by the Argus of what the present system is costing the public in these works -

quote.para: Meanwhile the public are paying a weekly bill on this work of .£1,700. There are those among the officials who declare that as much as 30 per cent, of the money is being wasted.

speech.para: That is a definite charge. Will the documents and records in the Department refute it and other charges? if the Government make no attempt to refute them, they must stand, and we are justified in telling our constituents that these things exist, and that under the a gis of the Labour Government 30 per cent, of the public money is being wasted and squandered because the party in power represent those who are employed J in these works. It is the business of the Government to disprove the charges, and, failing an adequate disproof, we are justified in assuming that they are true. Certainly, that will be my attitude.

talk.start.para: - Any fool can make charges.

- And any honest man when he is able to refute an unjust charge is only too ready to do so. It is when a man is not able to refute a charge that he shrinks and shrivels up, and looks ashamed of himself. I am sure the Minister of Home Affairs is now looking rather ashamed of himself in connexion with these matters. The inspectors in charge of these men are said to have reported them, and the following statement is made -

quote.para: It was bitterly complained in this report that no notice is taken of the complaints by inspectors of open defiance by the men. under them Even charges of assault were allowed to go unanswered as though they had never been made.

speech.para: If that be true, and in the absence of a denial, I assume that it is true-

talk.start.para: - Why should you assume? You are slandering the working men of this country.

- I am not making the statement. I simply accept a charge that has been made, and am justified in holding it to be true unless those who are interested choose to refute it. Under the state of things that has been disclosed, there can be no discipline. If the Government are going to enter upon the great public undertakings of this country by a system of day labour, under which there can be no discipline, they are going to pay anything from 1 5 to 30 or 50 per cent, more than they ought to pay. That is a serious position for the taxpayers to face. The Argus goes on to assert -

quote.para: The fact is that there is enough evidence in the files of the Department to convict the Administration of the wanton use of public funds.

speech.para: Any "waster" with a plaintive tale can secure a place on a job, and remain there in defiance of inspectors and responsible permanent officers.

Nothing more damaging has ever come under my notice. That statement is made, not by a nondescript journal, but by a journal of known reputation in Victoria. It deliberately levels a charge against the administration of the Public Departments of the Commonwealth. The position will undoubtedly be grasped by the public of Australia where they see charges of this nature levelled against those in whom they have had confidence and whom they returned to power on 13th April two years ago. They will now say, " This is a serious thing that has come to pass. The cry of the Labour party at the last election was, ' Give us a trial.' They have had their trial, and this is the way they have justified it."

talk.start.para: .- I have listened with some degree of pleasure to the honorable member for Echuca, because I never thought he had so much of the pugilistic element in his composition as he has shown to-night. He has told the Committee that he disapproves of the expenditure of money in the Northern Territory, but he bases his disagreement on the smallness of the population there, and not on the necessities of the Territory or the danger to Australia of its emptiness. This 1 ' large Australian " bases his opposition upon something that he cannot remedy, and refuses to encourage the Government to spend money in order to make the Territory fit for occupation by white men, and so help to remove the danger that is alleged to exist in that part of the continent. I cannot see the logic of his contention. I take it that if there were a large population there, he would be prepared to spend millions, but he knows, as well as I do, that we cannot get a large population into the Northern Territory without spending money. We shall have to watch what is done there in order to see whether the money is spent wisely or not. 1 desire to compliment the Government 01 the progressive policy embodied in these' Estimates with regard to the expansion of the telegraphic and telephonic systems, and with regard also to improvements that are to be made to a very large degree in the post-offices of the Commonwealth. I have, never since I have been a member of Parliament, seen Estimates presented which have shown so markedly that the Government had the courage to do the right thing in a proper way. The Postal Department has been starved from the beginning of Federation, and even before, and I am pleased that at last a solid attempt is being made to remove the disabilities that have grown out of an imperfect system. I hope the Minister of Home Affairs will see, not only that the money is spent, but that it is spent well, and that the post-offices that are to be built are constructed with a due regard to the exigencies of a growing population, and hygienic conditions, while seeing that the internal arrangements are such as to enable economies to be effected in management, and supervision improved. By these means, both the public and the men who serve the public will be made more contented. Any man can spend money, but to spend money wisely requires keen supervision and a keen determination to get the best value for it. Those of us who represent country districts will be delighted to know that, so far as concerns telegraphic and telephonic facilities, although all the money available last year was not spent, largely, I believe, on account of the scarcity of labour, and partly on account of the scarcity of material owing to labour disruptions in other lands, the money is nevertheless there to spend this year, and that we are likely to have sufficient labour in Australia to enable us to fulfil our obligations in that regard. I am proud to see that money has been placed on the Estimates, so that it cannot be said that Parliament has not been liberal in respect to giving the Government money to provide facilities in country districts. The telephone is the greatest civilizer at our command. It brings people together who would otherwise be far apart. It is an economizer of time. By its means the man in the back-blocks is brought into close juxtaposition with the man in the city. It is the means of saving money. It is often the means of saving lives. It helps to preserve health. The extension of these facilities in the country is the most useful work which the Government can take in hand, as every telephone line that we construct adds to the comfort, the welfare, and the happiness ox the community. I am in the happy position o* being able to acknowledge that this Government are doing things more rapidly than they have ever before been done by any Government in Australia - State or Federal. Probably our friends opposite will reply, "Yes, but you have the money." The answer is that we have had to devise ways and means for obtaining the money. We had the courage to initiate a policy that would bring in money, and when we got it, we had the courage to spend it for the benefit of the people. In regard to the expenditure of the money, it is inevitable that, in organizing a system in connexion with the various ramifications of Government work throughout the country, difficulties should be experienced. During the last two years the obligation has been laid upon this Government., not only to lay the foundation of a new system, but to introduce very rapidly - perhaps too rapidly - the day-labour system of carrying on public works. I wish the members of the Opposition would be reasonable and recognise that a change of system necessarily brings us face to face with difficulties. You meet with men who do not " fill the bill." You meet with many men who are unsympathetic towards the policy you have in view. You meet with men who are not competent for the work they are appointed to perform. That is the root of the complaint with regard to day labour in our Public Service. We have, first of all, to get the right men, and then to allot them to the employment for which they are fitted. The same difficulties are being experienced by the Government as are experienced by private employers. Do honorable members opposite mean to tell me that every private employer - every man who has men working for him - is getting full satisfaction out of all of them? I will venture to say that under the labour conditions that exist in Australia there is not one employer of any note, who is employing any considerable number of men, who has not to put up with many whom he would rather be without, because he cannot get better at present. The same thing must happen to the Government. I do say - and I say this definitely - that I regard much that is happening in connexion with the day-labour system with sorrow. I wish well to the system. I know that it is capable of good results. I regard with keen regret the fact that a section of the men who are being employed are not giving that return to the country that is due from them on account of the money which they receive, lt is of no use to mince matters. Any man who knows anything about work, who knows the value of work, and who knows what should be done for a fair day's wage, cannot, if he goes along and watches many men at work, say that he is wholly satisfied with existing conditions. We are not getting the results that we should have in connexion with our public works, whether in the Federal or State arena. There are- men who get into the Service, just as there are men who get into private employment, who will not do the fair thing. In a private employer's service there is a way of dealing with them. The same ought to be the case in the Public Service. The sooner the Minister recognises that, and the sooner he gets rid of an element which, if continued, is going to disintegrate the system and undermine the interests of the better class of workmen, the better it will be for his own comfort and for the welfare of the Department which he controls. The Minister ought to have the courage to say, " We do not want )'0u, if you are not prepared to give the Government a fair return for the money we pay you." If it were known that such was the attitude of the Minister, and that he was prepared to enforce it, I venture to say that the trouble would disappear within a reasonable time. I remember when, in New South Wales, the Hon. E. W. O'sullivan, as Minister of Public Works, introduced a new system for the benefit of the worker. His object was to cut out the contractor, so as to secure that his profit should be divided between the worker and the Government. His intentions were of the best, but his heart was too big. When a man came to O'sullivan and made an appeal to him, he could not resist it. I tell the Minister that he will never succeed while he allows men to touch the sympathetic side of his nature, and make it control the reasoning side, with the consequence of inducing him to put on again undeserving men who have been turned off. The result in New South Wales was that the new system fell into disrepute, and was banished from the arena of politics. The same will happen here, unless we have in charge a Minister who will have the courage to do the right thing. Men should not be allowed to override just discipline; because it must be remembered that no employes are treated so well as are those engaged on Government work. No man is asked to do more than a reasonable thing, and when men are properly treated and well paid, there is every reason why fair results should be expected from them. I say, with very great regret, that there is a section - not a large one, perhaps, but sufficiently large to injure the others - who are not doing the right thing to the Government that are employing them. Something has been said in the course of this debate about the appointment of a Public Works Committee. I feel that there is a necessity for something of the kind to be done. I do not think it is necessary to have such an elaborate system, such as exists in New South Wales, because we have not the same sort of work to do. But we certainly do need some kind of supervisory body or Committee of inquiry. If we had had such a Committee, many of the things which have been done in the Commonwealth would have been avoided, and money would have been saved. Take the money that was spent in the alteration of the Mail Branch at the Sydney General Post Office. That money would never have been expended if evidence had been taken beforehand as to the wisdom of the proposed alteration. The discomfort that has been caused to the men employed would have been avoided, and the disorganization that has, resulted would not have happened.
- The present system cannot go on, it seems to me.

- No; as I say, there is a lack of originality on the part of our permanent officers that is injurious to the Commonwealth. They have been brought up in a groove; they have been running in grooves for a number of years. They cannot get out of their grooves. Their environment is too restricted. They are unable to comply with the conditions which the people require to-day.
- Officers are not supposed to initiate a policy.

- But they are supposed to know how to improve existing conditions, and unless they are competent to meet the requirements of the country they are not fit for their positions. There is a lamentable lack of foresight on the part of the average public servant in Australia. No matter whether it be in the Public Works Department, the Postal Department, or even the Defence Department, we find a lack of originality all along the line. Men move in the performance of their duties as though they were mere automata, instead of reasoning beings.
- Not the junior officers.

- The junior officers are kept down. The trouble is that men have risen more because of seniority than by merit. The system of seniority which undoubtedly prevails has resulted in the putting of round pegs into square holes until we have practically everything filled with that which does not fit. There is in vogue a system under which, just as a man has obtained a thorough hold of the work of his Department, and is able to give to it some of his own individuality, his seniority entitles him to be appointed to a vacancy in another branch, of which he knows nothing. He goes from a branch of the Service for which he is most fitted to another branch of whose work he knows nothing. There he has again to learn his work from juniors; and so the system goes on. Under it, men are placed, not where they will give the best service, but in positions mapped out for them under the principle of promotion by seniority which is largely controlling our Service, and controlling it in the most injudicious and injurious manner. This has prevented progress throughout the Service. Under such a system we have men who are constantly learning their business instead of teaching others. The standard of the highest man is below what it ought to be, and as every man under him has to keep below it, the whole standard of the Service is reduced. I am pleased to be able to compliment the Government on having made a start in New South Wales, at all events, to take Federal works out of the hands of State officers, and to establish an independent Commonwealth Works Department in that State. That is a step in the right direction. Whether it should extend throughout the States, I am not in a position to say, but I certainly think it is a proper course to follow, seeing that the Public Works Department of New South Wales has proved, in a general sense, that it has no sympathy with the work that it has had to perform for the Federation. Federal works are with it a secondary consideration. If the State requires the services of the officers of the Department, Federal works must be set aside.

talker.party: LP; NAT from 1917
talker.name: MASSY-GREENE, Walter
Mr MASSY-GREENE

talk.start.para: - We could hardly expect otherwise.

- But see what it means ' for the Commonwealth - see what delay it involves. Then, again, for want of time, proper thought cannot always be given by State officers to F'ederal works, and plans that are ill-digested and inappropriate are often thrown down to the Commonwealth Government as the best that can be done for them.
- That means that the works cost more money.

- It also means the erection of buildings that are ill-adapted for the purposes for_ which they are required. In the days gone by, the last thing that was thought of in respect of plans for postal buildings, prepared by the Public Works Department of New South Wales, was their suitability for the services to be performed in them. Honorable members will find among our public offices buildings constructed without any regard for the needs of the people a decade ahead, when the population of the district will have increased, and the staff may have to be doubled. Then, again, in many cases little consideration has been given to hygienic requirements. I could point out in my own electorate ill-lighted, ill-ventilated, and even insanitary public buildings, no thought having been given to the necessity for providing for good ventilation, ample lighting, and economy in management. During the last twelve months I have examined plans from which most of these essentials to the welfare of the Public Service and the contentment of the people to be served were missing. These facts show that State officers in the past have not had a due comprehension of what is necessary in regard to our public buildings. The same state of affairs exists with regard to our public schools. Until two or three years ago our public school buildings throughout New South Wales were a disgrace to us. There was no attempt to observe modern conditions in any sense or form. There is some argument to support the appointment of a Public Works Committee, or a body of inquiry to guide the Government, or to indorse the suggestions that may be made from time to time. Such a body might prevent a great deal of unwise expenditure, and would probably serve as a check upon those who were not too careful as to the cost of the proposed works.
- It would also inform the House.

- It could afford information required by the Parliament and the public. The honorable member for Perth has referred to re- votes appearing on these Estimates. I am sorry that so much of the money voted last year was unexpended, but I would far rather see it re-voted than dropped off the Estimates altogether. That being so, I am not going to quarrel about these re-votes.
- It is a question, not of re-voting the money, but of expending money already voted.

- The failure to spend money voted for various works was due to two or three conditions, for which there is a satisfactory explanation. The honorable member for Perth complained that a sum of only £5,000 had been placed on these Estimates for the erection of a new post-office at Perth.I am rather pleased to know that the Postmaster-General has decided to erect a new postal building in that city before a catastrophe occurs in the ramshackle building now being used for postal purposes. One of the strongest features of the attack made by the Postmaster-General upon the report of the Postal Commission was that it recommended that the new post-office at Perth should be built near the railway station. It was incredible, he said, that any body of men should make such a recommendation. It is pleasing to me, as a member of that Commission, to know that the same honorable member now indorses that recommendation, and that the new building is to be erected in the locality recommended by the Commission. Incidents like these make a man think. The Government propose to spend £5,000 oa that work this year. The land is not yet bought.
- Yes, it is. The whole matter has been settled.

- The purchase has not yet been completed ; or, at all events, the land has not been paid for. I know that that means that the plans have not yet been commenced. By the time the plans are prepared, and the Department is ready for action, three parts of the year will have passed, and £5,000 will be ample to cover what can be spent by the Government during the remainder of the financial year. I think, in the circumstances, that it is wise to provide only for an amount which the Government can anticipate as likely to be spent. With regard to public works generally, I believe that the Minister of Home Affairs will be well advised if he were to appoint some competent person to the position of perambulating Inspector of Works. We should have an officer whose duty it would be to go from one place to another where men are employed on Commonwealth public works, to supervise the works generally, and see that the men employed upon them are doing their duty to the Government by whom they are employed. It may be said that we have gangers employed on each work, but in connexion with great public undertakings it is a common practice to have one supervising inspector who has a general knowledge of the whole of the works undertaken, long experience, courage to do the right thing, and just enough not to do the wrong thing. Such an officer, visiting works at unstated times, may do useful service, not in slave driving, hut in keeping in their proper place men who might otherwise become too closely associated with a local ganger. If the Minister of Home Affairs were to appoint such an officer, he would, by that, one act, remove much of the cause for the complaints and reports about which we have heard so much during the past few weeks.
. - In view of the fact that honorable members were travelling overnight, and are now a little tired, the Prime Minister might consent to report progress.

talker.party: ALP
talker.name: FISHER, Andrew
Mr FISHER

talk.start.para: . - I mav he allowed to make a short statement respecting the business of the House. The Leader of the Opposition will agree with me that it is advisable to get the Works Estimates out of the way before we begin a discussion upon the general Estimates. It is necessary to get these Estimates through as soon as practicable, and, in order to do so, we may have to sit a little later to-morrow. Friday is set apart for ether purposes, and I hope that, during to-morrow and Thursday, we shall be able to make certain of getting these Works Estimates through. It would be as well if there were a tacit understanding amongst honorable members to that effect.
.- I shall be very happy to expedite the passing of these Estimates, but at present I am quite unacquainted with the particular questions which may arise in connexion with them.
- They may be dealt with in the debate on the Budget.
- The honorable gentleman can get the sting in during the Budget debate.

- There may be as much time taken in avoiding the sting as in using it. I think that, after all, the Prime Minister's proposal is, perhaps, the best at present. We should endeavour to finish these Estimates before we begin the consideration of the general Estimates. Any criticism that has been offered to-night has come as much from one side as from the other.
- I have no objection to it at all ; but it would not be reasonable to carry the discussion of these Works Estimates into another week.

- All I can say is that I am not aware- of any intention to delay their passing unduly. But I know that there is the intention to speak on a number of the proposed votes. I shall not unduly occupy time in discussing them.

speech.para: Progress reported.
